elements.text: [Part One]

This is Earth Colony Phoenix calling on all frequencies. Can anyone hear me? Please, we need urgent assistance. This is Earth Colony Phoenix, located on the fourth planet of the Paladies star system. Repeat, we need urgent assistance. End recording, computer. Continue broadcasting that on the current schedule. Rotate through the entire frequency spectrum. Huh, for what it’s worth. There’s no one out there, is there, Butler?
(a robot) Statistically there are billions upon billions of lifeforms in the cosmos, ma’am.
Don’t be so pedantic. You know what I mean.
It would appear to be the case that there are no other lifeforms in the range of our communication equipment.
I keep hoping.
Your faith does you credit.
Does it?
Latest data from Medusa shows that we are continuing to suffer from very high levels of sunspot activity. The radiation belts will be particularly dense today. Perhaps tomorrow...
Tomorrow is another day, eh? Not for all of us, Butler. Not for all of us.
You know, there’s an art to the building up of dramatic tension. Sorry, old girl.
Do you mind? Less of the old.
Ah, Peri. I er, I didn’t see you there.
You do know that talking to yourself is the first sign of madness, don’t you? So, what are you doing, giving the Tardis its 10,000 year oil change?
Well, if you must know, I’m just trying to realign the temporal drift circuits. Somewhere along the line we’ve got a little out of phase. Happy now?
Totally.
Well, you did ask. We'll be back to normal flight in no time.
Whatever that means on board a time ship.
Look on the bright side, Peri. Be positive. Take advantage of having a little, what do you call it, personal time.
Personal time?

Yes. Why don’t you and Erimem take the chance to enjoy some good old-fashioned R&R. That's rest and relaxation. Just what the Doctor ordered. There’s plenty to do around here if you want to enjoy yourselves. Why don’t you go for a swim?
That might be a bit difficult. The pool’s still frozen.
Well, ice skating, then. I take it you were teaching Erimem how to skate.
Actually, Doctor, it was Erimem that I wanted to talk to you about. She’s been a bit quiet lately.
Ah, of course. Ever since...
Ever since Tibet, yes.
I was worried this might happen. And has she spoken to you about what happened?
A little. I don’t think she can face talking about it quite yet. It’s a complicated area, girls and their fathers. Trust me.

Oh, I do, Peri. It’s one area of expertise I don’t think I’m ever going to know much about. Poor Erimem. I know it must have been very hard for her, but she’s young, she'll bounce back. I’m sure she'll be back to normal soon.
Just a matter of time, eh?
You said you wanted to talk to me about her.
I was wondering. Well, actually I was wondering if you were regretting asking her to travel with us.
Regret? Oh no, no. I’ve never been one for regrets.
I was worried you might prefer to have just one travelling companion. Two’s company, and all that.

No, no, no, not at all. I’m happy with this crew. Two companions suits me fine. The more the merrier, as I used to say to Adric and Nyssa. And er Tegan. Well, maybe not. You can have too much of a good thing, I suppose.
Are you sure about that?
Of course I am. Look, why don’t you go and try to find her. See how she is.
But how will I ever find her? She could be anywhere. And these corridors go on for ever.
Running water. Ducks quacking.
Erimem?
I’m over here. Have we landed somewhere?
No, not yet. The Doctor’s making some repairs or something.
Is there something wrong with the Tardis?
When isn’t there? Don’t worry about it, I’m sure it’s nothing.
I’m not worried.
I didn’t mean to suggest you were. Nice room you’ve found, if room’s the right word. I couldn’t believe it when I opened the door and stepped into this field.
It’s wonderful, isn’t it? And it looks like it goes on for miles, but I’m sure it’s just some kind of illusion.
A very good one, though. Is that some kind of road in the distance?
It can’t be, can it?
If you squint you can almost think you can see traffic, but that would be impossible.
No, it’s no good. I can’t see anything moving.
Must be my eyes playing tricks on me.
Or mine.
I’m sorry. That was thoughtless of me. How are your eyes?
Better, most of the time. I’m a bit sensitive to bright light, but these, what did you call them? Shades? These have helped a lot.
They suit you. Who knew the wardrobe rooms had anything so stylish in them. I’m glad you're getting over what happened on the mountainside. I was worried you might be thinking leaving us.
I cannot lie to you, Peri. I have been thinking about that.
Erimem, no.

It’s true. I thought travelling with you and the Doctor would be exciting, an adventure in learning. But all I seem to be learning about is myself, and I’m not sure I’ve liked the lessons I’ve learnt.
You mustn’t let one bad experience colour your ideas about travelling with us. We’ve had fun in other places we’ve been to, haven’t we?
If you count nearly getting killed, and running away from men and beasts with weapons, and getting involved with danger at every turn as fun, I suppose.
It’s not always like that.
Isn’t it?
No, it’s not. I’ve not been travelling with the Doctor long, but already I’ve seen such fantastic things. Sights I'll remember for the rest of my life. Don’t give up on us now.
(sighs) I used to be a queen, a god. I knew who I was and what I was for. But now, I just don’t know any more.
Oh, come on. Don’t get maudlin. You’ve been given an opportunity to travel all through Time and Space. A chance most people can only dream of. Embrace it, go with the flow.
Go with the flow?

It means take life as it comes. Don’t sweat the small stuff. Que sera sera. It’s like a rollercoaster ride in the dark. You never know if you’re about to go up or down, but you know it’s going to be wild.
I don’t know what a rollercoaster is, but it doesn’t sound much fun.
You have no idea. Next time we’re on Earth in the twentieth century, you and me are going to check out some serious thrill rides.
But when will that be?
I don’t know why, but the Tardis always seems to be going back to Earth. I'll bet that’s where we’re going now. Probably England. You wait and see. Now, which direction is the door?
You didn’t close it behind you, did you? We'll never find it if you did.
Of course I didn’t. At least I don’t think I did. Now listen to me. I’m getting as bad as the Doctor. Come on, let’s start looking.
Communication channels to all cells now open. Begin broadcasting now.

Thank you, computer. Citizens of Earth Colony Phoenix, this is the voice of Auntie. May I please have your full attention. Thank you. I am pleased to be able to bring you all good news. Our latest probes have detected a reduction in strength in the radiation field, which means we have the opportunity for some of you to return today. As you know, it is extremely dangerous to punch a transit signal through the interference of the radiation belt. Only the fittest of you can take that risk. The system computers have made an evaluation, and you will be informed of your own individual status shortly. For the last fifty long years, we have had to be both strong and patient. But even during our years of exile, many of our people have made it home, and soon, yes soon, we will all get there. To celebrate this latest return, I am happy to announce that today will be a Social. At 1800 hours, the internal teleport system will be on open access for three hours. As with all Socials, I advise you all to think carefully about who it is you wish to share this time with. Remember, social contact is a privilege. Choose your social partner with care, and enjoy the Social. This is the voice of Auntie, signing off.
Communication channels now closed.
Thank goodness.
Door opens and closes.
Have I missed your address, Auntie?
Yes, it is done.
I am sorry I missed it. You are always so positive when you speak to the colonists. I find it very inspirational.
I am an old hand, dear Butler, that’s all. Lay it on thick for the masses, such as they are.
You do what you have to do. You have responsibilities.
Don’t I just.
Your decisions are always logical.
Is that meant to make me feel better?
Logic is always a better foundation than emotion on which to base a decision.
For you, maybe, but you were made that way. I am a human being, and we’re not so good at dealing with things in such black and white terms. At least, we shouldn’t be.
I am curious about one thing, though. I have scanned the list for today’s return. You have not selected colonist 478.
Bellip? I couldn’t face... I want her with me.
I understand.
Goodness, what’s happened to us?
Since the colony was founded on this planet fifty years ago, the human population has declined

Stop. Stop. That was a rhetorical question. I don’t need a history lesson. I was there. You know, I remember the real Socials. Parties, get-togethers. People would meet together and talk, eat, drink, maybe even dance. I used to like to dance.
Would you like me to dance with you, ma’am? I have been programmed with a number of traditional human dance steps.
It wouldn’t be the same. Dance is what free humans do, not creatures who live lives in isolation like caged animals.
The colonists have chosen to live like this over the years. Perhaps they are happier this way.
Happy? Do you really think these people are happy? Don’t you know anything about humanity?
I know you lead this colony with wisdom and compassion, ma’am, and that you should not doubt yourself.
You’re programmed to agree with me. How can I trust your opinion about anything?

Right. Let’s try this again. Hello, Bellip. It’s me, Larog. She can see that, idiot, if she’s activated her video circuit. Okay, start again. Hi, Bellip. How are you? I was er, wondering if you’d had any thoughts about the Social today? Oh no, no, no. That’s no good. What if she just says no to that. Where do you go from there, Laroq? Oh, this is hopeless. The more I rehearse this, the worse it gets. Computer.
(unintelligible)
Open a communication channel to colonist 478 Bellip.
Channel is open. Communication accepted. Audio channel opening. You may proceed.
[OC]: Hello?
Bellip? It’s me, Laroq. Please, activate your video circuits. I’d like to see you.
[OC]: I, I'd prefer not. Please don’t be offended.
Nothing you can do can offend me, Bellip. Are you well?
[OC]: I’ve been a little ill, but I’m better now. And you?
I’m good. I’m really good. My regime has been going well.
[OC]: I’m pleased to hear it.
I was wondering. Auntie has announced that there is to be a Social tonight.
[OC]: I know. I heard Auntie myself.
Have you chosen a Social partner?
[OC]: Oh, I don’t think I'll be taking part.
But Bellip, you should. It is good to see people, face to face, sometimes, isn’t it?
[OC]: Maybe. But it’s like I said, I’ve been ill. I need my own space.
I am sorry. I didn’t realise. But I don’t have to invade your space. I could just port in and stay on the transmat pad, just to see you.
[OC]: No. I’m sorry, not this time.
Does that mean perhaps next Social?
[OC]: Ye-es, perhaps. That might be very nice. I do like you, Laroq.
And I like you. That’s why I was looking forward to seeing you, face to face.
[OC]: Don’t waste the Social on my behalf, though. Why not meet up with Vidler?
Why would I want to spend even a minute of contact time with him?
[OC]: I thought he was your friend. You speak for hours on the channels, don’t you? Why not talk
face to face for a while?
He'll just go on about his conspiracy theories, as usual, especially if we’re in the same room, not on the public net. I’d rather see you.
[OC]: I’m sorry, Laroq, but I’m just not up to it this month. Be patient with me, please?
Whatever you want. Of course.
I still don’t understand. I walked for a long time before finding that place, but it’s taken no time to get back here.
That’s the Tardis for you. Go with the flow, remember?
I'll try.
We're landing?
Ah, there you both are. Jolly good. What was the question?
Peri asked if we were landing.
Yes, yes. I need to come out of the Vortex into real Space-Time to allow the adjustments I’ve been making to calibrate themselves.
And is it Earth?
We don't always land on Earth, you know.
(laughing) Just most of the time.
Right, let’s have a look where we are, shall we?
What will you give me if it isn’t Earth?
Are you serious?
I thought you were confident.
Okay then. A pedicure if I’m wrong.
I hope you know I heard all that. You have a witness to your wager, Erimem.
So what’s the answer, Doctor? Am I going to get this pedicure?
Scanner.
Oh dear.
No.
I don’t think that looks like Earth, does it?
What is that thing?
A space station. Looks a bit dead.
Does seem a bit dark, doesn’t it. Shall we take a closer look? I really do think I’m getting better at these short hops. Textbook landing. No complaints I trust, ladies?
You want a spontaneous round of applause?
You can save that for the next time you’re watching me bat.
Let’s hope that won’t be for a while. At least baseball only takes hours, not days.
Baseball?
Don’t ask.
No more signs of life inside than there was out, but life support is active. It'll be safe to explore.
But is there anything to see out there, except dust?
We'll never know if we don’t look. Coming?
Beats sitting around here, I guess.
That's the spirit, Peri. Always have an enquiring mind.
Tardis doors open.
Peri.
Yes?
What is a pedicure?
Tardis door closed. Walking on metal.
Spooky.
Do you think it’s haunted?
No. You need a creaky old mansion and cobwebs for that.
Over here, you two. Take a look at this.
All these screens. What is it, Mission Control?
Of a kind. This is the operational centre of the station, and these are observation screens.
Observing what?
The station is in geostationary orbit around planet, and the sensors and cameras are all trained on that landmass there.
Some kind of settlement?
Those are habitat domes. Looking at this technology, I'd say human, around 26". maybe 29" century.
So what's this place, some kind of automated watch tower?
It would appear so.
I wish we could see it for real, not just on a screen.
I expect there’ll be some sort of porthole around here somewhere, but be careful.
Erimem screams in the distance.
Erimem!
She wandered over that way.
Erimem, what happened?
It’s my eyes. I found the window and was watching the planet. It was so beautiful, so peaceful, and then suddenly...
The sun rose and blinded you.
It’s okay, it was just a shock. And my eyes are still sensitive. I’m sorry if I worried you.
Let me take a look.
I’m sure I'll be fine.
So, what’s the verdict?
I don’t think there’s any permanent damage, Erimem, but you might think about keeping these sunglasses on your nose rather than in your hair.
Why don’t we find somewhere to sit down, let your eyes recover a little.
If you don’t mind, I'll carry on taking a look at what you called Mission Control. See what I can find out from the computer systems. I’m surprised there’s so little sign of life here.
Well, if there was anything here, I think we’d have seen them by now. We’ve not exactly been creeping about like mice.
No, no, I’m sure that there’s no one else up here.
Now I am worried.
Thanks for the vote of confidence.
What about on the planet? Are there people there?
Those habitat domes suggest it’s a possibility. I'll try to find out.
Come on, Erimem, let’s leave him to work. That way looks likely.
Where’s the door handle then?
Some kind of sliding door. Maybe it’s stiff or something. I think it’s just stuck.
Don't hurt yourself.
Oh, don’t worry about me. Stubborn is my middle name (effort) and once I’ve decided to do something, I
Door creaks open.
I tend to do it. There.
Well done.
Alarm sounds.
Oh no.
Maybe there’s a reason the door didn’t want to open.
Don’t panic. Just a motion sensor.
Can you make it stop?
I should think so. Let’s have a look at that panel.
Alarm stops.
Is that you?
No. It just switched itself off. Nothing to worry about, I’m sure.
But the alarm?

Like I said, it just went off when the door opened. Nothing else has happened, has it? No bulkheads locking into place, no robot guards scrambling to the scene. Nothing at all. The fact of the matter is there’s no one else here to react to the alarm, is there.
I guess so.
Alarm.
That’s the space station, isn’t it?
I’m afraid so, ma’am.
Is it a fault? Some kind of surge in the circuits?
No, ma’am. It is more serious than that. It would appear there is activity on board the space station. At least three lifeforms.
It can’t be. Not yet. It’s too soon. We’re not ready.
It is possible that the lifeforms are harmless.
Harmless? What kind of creature is going to be casually travelling round here? No, I don't like this. I don’t like this at all.
Would you like me to investigate?
Yes. Port up there immediately.
As you wish, ma’am. Activate medium range transmat system, location Space Station Medusa.
Medium range transmat. Contact made.
Activate.
Arm your weapons, Butler. Be prepared.
Peri, we’ve come a long way inside the station. I know I wanted it dark but isn’t this a bit much?
And quiet. I wonder what this area was used for?
It seems even more abandoned than the control room.
I wonder why that alarm went off? Perhaps it’s a quarantine area.
The Doctor wouldn’t have let us wander off if there was any danger. At least, I don’t think he would.
I think this might be a generator room. Where the station’s power comes from.
What are those shapes piled up over there?
I don’t know. Could they be eggs?
If those are eggs, I wouldn’t want to see the chicken that laid them. They’re huge!
They are eggs, I’m sure of it. How many are there?
Dozens. No, more than that. Look, they go back further. Piles and piles of them.
Let me get a closer look.
Are you sure? It might be dangerous.
They’re just eggs. They’re not going to start hatching just because I touch them, are they? I just want to see if they're alive.
Be careful.
Treadmill whirring, breathless.
How much longer?
(mostly unintelligible) Sixteen minutes of cardiovascular exercise.
I can’t run any more. Stop the treadmill. (gasping) Thank you. (beep) Bellip, is that you? Did you change your mind? Oh, it’s you.
Who else was it going to be? Still doing your exercises. You obedient little lab rat.
I was bored.
You’re playing into their hands. You been avoiding the food?
Yes, Vidler, I have, and I’m starving. Are you sure it’s necessary?
Of course it is. Don’t you feel the difference?
I feel hungry.
Hungry but alert. I tell you, the food is stuffed with drugs to keep us docile.
Just a minute. The Social’s not due to start yet. How did you manage to port in here?
You see? You're thinking for yourself now.
But how?
Maybe I’m just smarter than the system computer.
What’s that meant to mean? Have you been hacking into central systems again?
Auntie never did prove that.
Vidler, you can’t keep breaking the rules!
Whyever not? If the rules are stupid, they deserve to be broken.
So you’ve hacked the transmat controls.
No, of course not. The system is always open, but most of the sheep in this colony are too timid to try and use the ports any other time.
People are happy in their personal space.
People don’t know what happy is.
And you’re going to change that, are you?
We are. You are still with us, Laroq?
You know I think we should have more freedom.
And this is the way to get it.
How?
By organising. That’s why I wanted us to avoid eating the drugged food. We're having a mass meet.
A what?
I want to get us all together, all the people I’ve been talking to for months. Think of it. It will be historic. The first political rally ever in the history of this planet.
How, how many?
How many what?
How many people?
I don’t know. Five, six? Maybe even eight people.
(panicking) In the same place? In one room?
Imagine it.
I am! Excuse me. I need some space.
Door opens and closes.
It’s nothing to be scared of, Larogq. It’s natural and it’s the future!
Colonist Bellip Auntie wishes to speak to you one to one.
To me? Okay, accept call.
[OC]: Colonist Bellip, are you well?
Auntie?
[OC]: Have you recovered from your illness?
Oh yes, I’m much better now. Much better. In fact, I’ve never been fitter. Are you calling me for any particular reason?
[OC]: You mean, have I news of the Return selection?
Yes. Have I made it? Am I going home?
[OC]: I’m sorry, Bellip.
But why? I’ve been eating full rations, completing and exceeding my exercise targets, even when I was ill.
[OC]: I know. And you are stronger than at your last evaluation, but not strong enough. It'll be too great a risk for you to try a Return today.
But I want to go home. I can’t bear this.
[OC]: You will return, I promise.
But you could change your mind, couldn’t you?
[OC]: No. The decision has been made. You will just have to be patient. I am sorry.
Nothing’s happening. Just eggs.
Peri, what do you think this is?
Hmm? Oh, no idea.
It’s just big enough for me to stand on.
Careful, you might set something off.
[OC]: Peri!
Hold on.
[OC]: I can’t get out of here. The door’s stuck. I’m trapped.
The colony was settled in the year 2835, fifty standard years ago.
Not bad, Doctor. Not bad. Computer, tell me, how many colonists are currently living on the planet?
Current figures are being collated. Please stand by.
Please stand away from the computers and make yourself known.
Ah. Company at last. I thought it wouldn’t be long.
Please move away as requested.
Shall I raise my arms and come quietly?
That would be appreciated.
Do you have a name or number? I’m the Doctor.
Doctor?
Just the Doctor. And you’re?
I am designated Butler. Just Butler. No definite article.
And are you in charge round here?
I am at the service of Auntie. She is the leader of the Earth Colony Phoenix.
A leader called Auntie, en? How cosy. I don’t suppose you were thinking of taking me to see this Auntie or are you going to throw me into some kind of tedious cell first?
It’s okay, Erimem, just stay calm. We got that sliding door open earlier, we can do this too.
[OC]: Quickly, please. I don’t like this.
Hang on. Must be a way to get it open again.
[OC]: Peri, this isn’t very pleasant. Hurry.
There’s some kind of control panel here, but there are no labels or markings.
[OC]: Try anything! Please, I don’t like this. I feel like I’m trapped in a sarcophagus.
Okay, okay. Don’t panic. Look, watch me through the window. I’m still here. Let’s see.
Tries various buttons.
[OC]: Peri!
Erimem!
Peri, where’s Erimem? What’s happening?
She was just in there. But she disappeared in front of my eyes. She just melted away!
It’s some kind of transmat device. Am I right, Butler?
You are correct, Butler. It is a transmat. This is the station power plant, but the transmat here is connected to the general colony systems.
Who’s your metal friend?
This is Butler, and technically we’re his prisoners.
Oh, terrific.
But we can deal with all that later. The priority is locating Erimem. Can you trace the port to a destination, Butler?
I am afraid that might not be possible.
Might not? What do you mean, might not?
The directional controls were scrambled when you attempted to open the transmat pod.
So it was a random port?
Your friend may have been sent to any one of a thousand port addresses in the colony.
You still said may. What else may have happened?
If the random coordinates do not relate to an actual port, your friend will never arrive anywhere.
So she should reappear back here.
No, Doctor. Her atoms will be scattered in space. I fear your friend might already be dead.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
AUNTIE: This is Earth Colony Phoenix calling on all frequencies. Can anyone hear me? Please, we need urgent assistance. This is Earth Colony Phoenix, located on the fourth planet of the Paladies star system. Repeat, we need urgent assistance. End recording, computer. Continue broadcasting that on the current schedule. Rotate through the entire frequency spectrum. Huh, for what it’s worth. There’s no one out there, is there, Butler?
BUTLER: (a robot) Statistically there are billions upon billions of lifeforms in the cosmos, ma’am.
AUNTIE: Don’t be so pedantic. You know what I mean.
BUTLER: It would appear to be the case that there are no other lifeforms in the range of our communication equipment.
AUNTIE: I keep hoping.
BUTLER: Your faith does you credit.
AUNTIE: Does it?
BUTLER: Latest data from Medusa shows that we are continuing to suffer from very high levels of sunspot activity. The radiation belts will be particularly dense today. Perhaps tomorrow...
AUNTIE: Tomorrow is another day, eh? Not for all of us, Butler. Not for all of us.
DOCTOR: You know, there’s an art to the building up of dramatic tension. Sorry, old girl.
PERI: Do you mind? Less of the old.
DOCTOR: Ah, Peri. I er, I didn’t see you there.
PERI: You do know that talking to yourself is the first sign of madness, don’t you? So, what are you doing, giving the Tardis its 10,000 year oil change?
DOCTOR: Well, if you must know, I’m just trying to realign the temporal drift circuits. Somewhere along the line we’ve got a little out of phase. Happy now?
PERI: Totally.
DOCTOR: Well, you did ask. We'll be back to normal flight in no time.
PERI: Whatever that means on board a time ship.
DOCTOR: Look on the bright side, Peri. Be positive. Take advantage of having a little, what do you call it, personal time.
PERI: Personal time?
DOCTOR: Yes. Why don’t you and Erimem take the chance to enjoy some good old-fashioned R&R. That's rest and relaxation. Just what the Doctor ordered. There’s plenty to do around here if you want to enjoy yourselves. Why don’t you go for a swim?
PERI: That might be a bit difficult. The pool’s still frozen.
DOCTOR: Well, ice skating, then. I take it you were teaching Erimem how to skate.
PERI: Actually, Doctor, it was Erimem that I wanted to talk to you about. She’s been a bit quiet lately.
DOCTOR: Ah, of course. Ever since...
PERI: Ever since Tibet, yes.
DOCTOR: I was worried this might happen. And has she spoken to you about what happened?
PERI: A little. I don’t think she can face talking about it quite yet. It’s a complicated area, girls and their fathers. Trust me.
DOCTOR: Oh, I do, Peri. It’s one area of expertise I don’t think I’m ever going to know much about. Poor Erimem. I know it must have been very hard for her, but she’s young, she'll bounce back. I’m sure she'll be back to normal soon.
PERI: Just a matter of time, eh?
DOCTOR: You said you wanted to talk to me about her.
PERI: I was wondering. Well, actually I was wondering if you were regretting asking her to travel with us.
DOCTOR: Regret? Oh no, no. I’ve never been one for regrets.
PERI: I was worried you might prefer to have just one travelling companion. Two’s company, and all that.
DOCTOR: No, no, no, not at all. I’m happy with this crew. Two companions suits me fine. The more the merrier, as I used to say to Adric and Nyssa. And er Tegan. Well, maybe not. You can have too much of a good thing, I suppose.
PERI: Are you sure about that?
DOCTOR: Of course I am. Look, why don’t you go and try to find her. See how she is.
PERI: But how will I ever find her? She could be anywhere. And these corridors go on for ever.
PERI: Erimem?
ERIMEM: I’m over here. Have we landed somewhere?
PERI: No, not yet. The Doctor’s making some repairs or something.
ERIMEM: Is there something wrong with the Tardis?
PERI: When isn’t there? Don’t worry about it, I’m sure it’s nothing.
ERIMEM: I’m not worried.
PERI: I didn’t mean to suggest you were. Nice room you’ve found, if room’s the right word. I couldn’t believe it when I opened the door and stepped into this field.
ERIMEM: It’s wonderful, isn’t it? And it looks like it goes on for miles, but I’m sure it’s just some kind of illusion.
PERI: A very good one, though. Is that some kind of road in the distance?
ERIMEM: It can’t be, can it?
PERI: If you squint you can almost think you can see traffic, but that would be impossible.
ERIMEM: No, it’s no good. I can’t see anything moving.
PERI: Must be my eyes playing tricks on me.
ERIMEM: Or mine.
PERI: I’m sorry. That was thoughtless of me. How are your eyes?
ERIMEM: Better, most of the time. I’m a bit sensitive to bright light, but these, what did you call them? Shades? These have helped a lot.
PERI: They suit you. Who knew the wardrobe rooms had anything so stylish in them. I’m glad you're getting over what happened on the mountainside. I was worried you might be thinking leaving us.
ERIMEM: I cannot lie to you, Peri. I have been thinking about that.
PERI: Erimem, no.
ERIMEM: It’s true. I thought travelling with you and the Doctor would be exciting, an adventure in learning. But all I seem to be learning about is myself, and I’m not sure I’ve liked the lessons I’ve learnt.
PERI: You mustn’t let one bad experience colour your ideas about travelling with us. We’ve had fun in other places we’ve been to, haven’t we?
ERIMEM: If you count nearly getting killed, and running away from men and beasts with weapons, and getting involved with danger at every turn as fun, I suppose.
PERI: It’s not always like that.
ERIMEM: Isn’t it?
PERI: No, it’s not. I’ve not been travelling with the Doctor long, but already I’ve seen such fantastic things. Sights I'll remember for the rest of my life. Don’t give up on us now.
ERIMEM: (sighs) I used to be a queen, a god. I knew who I was and what I was for. But now, I just don’t know any more.
PERI: Oh, come on. Don’t get maudlin. You’ve been given an opportunity to travel all through Time and Space. A chance most people can only dream of. Embrace it, go with the flow.
ERIMEM: Go with the flow?
PERI: It means take life as it comes. Don’t sweat the small stuff. Que sera sera. It’s like a rollercoaster ride in the dark. You never know if you’re about to go up or down, but you know it’s going to be wild.
ERIMEM: I don’t know what a rollercoaster is, but it doesn’t sound much fun.
PERI: You have no idea. Next time we’re on Earth in the twentieth century, you and me are going to check out some serious thrill rides.
ERIMEM: But when will that be?
PERI: I don’t know why, but the Tardis always seems to be going back to Earth. I'll bet that’s where we’re going now. Probably England. You wait and see. Now, which direction is the door?
ERIMEM: You didn’t close it behind you, did you? We'll never find it if you did.
PERI: Of course I didn’t. At least I don’t think I did. Now listen to me. I’m getting as bad as the Doctor. Come on, let’s start looking.
COMPUTER: Communication channels to all cells now open. Begin broadcasting now.
AUNTIE: Thank you, computer. Citizens of Earth Colony Phoenix, this is the voice of Auntie. May I please have your full attention. Thank you. I am pleased to be able to bring you all good news. Our latest probes have detected a reduction in strength in the radiation field, which means we have the opportunity for some of you to return today. As you know, it is extremely dangerous to punch a transit signal through the interference of the radiation belt. Only the fittest of you can take that risk. The system computers have made an evaluation, and you will be informed of your own individual status shortly. For the last fifty long years, we have had to be both strong and patient. But even during our years of exile, many of our people have made it home, and soon, yes soon, we will all get there. To celebrate this latest return, I am happy to announce that today will be a Social. At 1800 hours, the internal teleport system will be on open access for three hours. As with all Socials, I advise you all to think carefully about who it is you wish to share this time with. Remember, social contact is a privilege. Choose your social partner with care, and enjoy the Social. This is the voice of Auntie, signing off.
COMPUTER: Communication channels now closed.
AUNTIE: Thank goodness.
BUTLER: Have I missed your address, Auntie?
AUNTIE: Yes, it is done.
BUTLER: I am sorry I missed it. You are always so positive when you speak to the colonists. I find it very inspirational.
AUNTIE: I am an old hand, dear Butler, that’s all. Lay it on thick for the masses, such as they are.
BUTLER: You do what you have to do. You have responsibilities.
AUNTIE: Don’t I just.
BUTLER: Your decisions are always logical.
AUNTIE: Is that meant to make me feel better?
BUTLER: Logic is always a better foundation than emotion on which to base a decision.
AUNTIE: For you, maybe, but you were made that way. I am a human being, and we’re not so good at dealing with things in such black and white terms. At least, we shouldn’t be.
BUTLER: I am curious about one thing, though. I have scanned the list for today’s return. You have not selected colonist 478.
AUNTIE: Bellip? I couldn’t face... I want her with me.
BUTLER: I understand.
AUNTIE: Goodness, what’s happened to us?
BUTLER: Since the colony was founded on this planet fifty years ago, the human population has declined
AUNTIE: Stop. Stop. That was a rhetorical question. I don’t need a history lesson. I was there. You know, I remember the real Socials. Parties, get-togethers. People would meet together and talk, eat, drink, maybe even dance. I used to like to dance.
BUTLER: Would you like me to dance with you, ma’am? I have been programmed with a number of traditional human dance steps.
AUNTIE: It wouldn’t be the same. Dance is what free humans do, not creatures who live lives in isolation like caged animals.
BUTLER: The colonists have chosen to live like this over the years. Perhaps they are happier this way.
AUNTIE: Happy? Do you really think these people are happy? Don’t you know anything about humanity?
BUTLER: I know you lead this colony with wisdom and compassion, ma’am, and that you should not doubt yourself.
AUNTIE: You’re programmed to agree with me. How can I trust your opinion about anything?
LAROQ: Right. Let’s try this again. Hello, Bellip. It’s me, Larog. She can see that, idiot, if she’s activated her video circuit. Okay, start again. Hi, Bellip. How are you? I was er, wondering if you’d had any thoughts about the Social today? Oh no, no, no. That’s no good. What if she just says no to that. Where do you go from there, Laroq? Oh, this is hopeless. The more I rehearse this, the worse it gets. Computer.
COMPUTER: (unintelligible)
LAROQ: Open a communication channel to colonist 478 Bellip.
COMPUTER: Channel is open. Communication accepted. Audio channel opening. You may proceed.
BELLIP: [OC]: Hello?
LAROQ: Bellip? It’s me, Laroq. Please, activate your video circuits. I’d like to see you.
BELLIP: [OC]: I, I'd prefer not. Please don’t be offended.
LAROQ: Nothing you can do can offend me, Bellip. Are you well?
BELLIP: [OC]: I’ve been a little ill, but I’m better now. And you?
LAROQ: I’m good. I’m really good. My regime has been going well.
BELLIP: [OC]: I’m pleased to hear it.
LAROQ: I was wondering. Auntie has announced that there is to be a Social tonight.
BELLIP: [OC]: I know. I heard Auntie myself.
LAROQ: Have you chosen a Social partner?
BELLIP: [OC]: Oh, I don’t think I'll be taking part.
LAROQ: But Bellip, you should. It is good to see people, face to face, sometimes, isn’t it?
BELLIP: [OC]: Maybe. But it’s like I said, I’ve been ill. I need my own space.
LAROQ: I am sorry. I didn’t realise. But I don’t have to invade your space. I could just port in and stay on the transmat pad, just to see you.
BELLIP: [OC]: No. I’m sorry, not this time.
LAROQ: Does that mean perhaps next Social?
BELLIP: [OC]: Ye-es, perhaps. That might be very nice. I do like you, Laroq.
LAROQ: And I like you. That’s why I was looking forward to seeing you, face to face.
BELLIP: [OC]: Don’t waste the Social on my behalf, though. Why not meet up with Vidler?
LAROQ: Why would I want to spend even a minute of contact time with him?
BELLIP: [OC]: I thought he was your friend. You speak for hours on the channels, don’t you? Why not talk
BELLIP: face to face for a while?
LAROQ: He'll just go on about his conspiracy theories, as usual, especially if we’re in the same room, not on the public net. I’d rather see you.
BELLIP: [OC]: I’m sorry, Laroq, but I’m just not up to it this month. Be patient with me, please?
LAROQ: Whatever you want. Of course.
ERIMEM: I still don’t understand. I walked for a long time before finding that place, but it’s taken no time to get back here.
PERI: That’s the Tardis for you. Go with the flow, remember?
ERIMEM: I'll try.
PERI: We're landing?
DOCTOR: Ah, there you both are. Jolly good. What was the question?
ERIMEM: Peri asked if we were landing.
DOCTOR: Yes, yes. I need to come out of the Vortex into real Space-Time to allow the adjustments I’ve been making to calibrate themselves.
ERIMEM: And is it Earth?
DOCTOR: We don't always land on Earth, you know.
PERI: (laughing) Just most of the time.
DOCTOR: Right, let’s have a look where we are, shall we?
ERIMEM: What will you give me if it isn’t Earth?
PERI: Are you serious?
ERIMEM: I thought you were confident.
PERI: Okay then. A pedicure if I’m wrong.
DOCTOR: I hope you know I heard all that. You have a witness to your wager, Erimem.
ERIMEM: So what’s the answer, Doctor? Am I going to get this pedicure?
DOCTOR: Oh dear.
PERI: No.
DOCTOR: I don’t think that looks like Earth, does it?
ERIMEM: What is that thing?
PERI: A space station. Looks a bit dead.
DOCTOR: Does seem a bit dark, doesn’t it. Shall we take a closer look? I really do think I’m getting better at these short hops. Textbook landing. No complaints I trust, ladies?
PERI: You want a spontaneous round of applause?
DOCTOR: You can save that for the next time you’re watching me bat.
PERI: Let’s hope that won’t be for a while. At least baseball only takes hours, not days.
ERIMEM: Baseball?
PERI: Don’t ask.
DOCTOR: No more signs of life inside than there was out, but life support is active. It'll be safe to explore.
ERIMEM: But is there anything to see out there, except dust?
DOCTOR: We'll never know if we don’t look. Coming?
PERI: Beats sitting around here, I guess.
DOCTOR: That's the spirit, Peri. Always have an enquiring mind.
ERIMEM: Peri.
PERI: Yes?
ERIMEM: What is a pedicure?
PERI: Spooky.
ERIMEM: Do you think it’s haunted?
PERI: No. You need a creaky old mansion and cobwebs for that.
DOCTOR: Over here, you two. Take a look at this.
PERI: All these screens. What is it, Mission Control?
DOCTOR: Of a kind. This is the operational centre of the station, and these are observation screens.
PERI: Observing what?
DOCTOR: The station is in geostationary orbit around planet, and the sensors and cameras are all trained on that landmass there.
PERI: Some kind of settlement?
DOCTOR: Those are habitat domes. Looking at this technology, I'd say human, around 26". maybe 29" century.
PERI: So what's this place, some kind of automated watch tower?
DOCTOR: It would appear so.
PERI: I wish we could see it for real, not just on a screen.
DOCTOR: I expect there’ll be some sort of porthole around here somewhere, but be careful.
DOCTOR: Erimem!
PERI: She wandered over that way.
DOCTOR: Erimem, what happened?
ERIMEM: It’s my eyes. I found the window and was watching the planet. It was so beautiful, so peaceful, and then suddenly...
DOCTOR: The sun rose and blinded you.
ERIMEM: It’s okay, it was just a shock. And my eyes are still sensitive. I’m sorry if I worried you.
DOCTOR: Let me take a look.
ERIMEM: I’m sure I'll be fine.
PERI: So, what’s the verdict?
DOCTOR: I don’t think there’s any permanent damage, Erimem, but you might think about keeping these sunglasses on your nose rather than in your hair.
PERI: Why don’t we find somewhere to sit down, let your eyes recover a little.
DOCTOR: If you don’t mind, I'll carry on taking a look at what you called Mission Control. See what I can find out from the computer systems. I’m surprised there’s so little sign of life here.
PERI: Well, if there was anything here, I think we’d have seen them by now. We’ve not exactly been creeping about like mice.
DOCTOR: No, no, I’m sure that there’s no one else up here.
PERI: Now I am worried.
DOCTOR: Thanks for the vote of confidence.
ERIMEM: What about on the planet? Are there people there?
DOCTOR: Those habitat domes suggest it’s a possibility. I'll try to find out.
PERI: Come on, Erimem, let’s leave him to work. That way looks likely.
ERIMEM: Where’s the door handle then?
PERI: Some kind of sliding door. Maybe it’s stiff or something. I think it’s just stuck.
ERIMEM: Don't hurt yourself.
PERI: Oh, don’t worry about me. Stubborn is my middle name (effort) and once I’ve decided to do something, I
PERI: I tend to do it. There.
ERIMEM: Well done.
ERIMEM: Oh no.
PERI: Maybe there’s a reason the door didn’t want to open.
DOCTOR: Don’t panic. Just a motion sensor.
ERIMEM: Can you make it stop?
DOCTOR: I should think so. Let’s have a look at that panel.
PERI: Is that you?
DOCTOR: No. It just switched itself off. Nothing to worry about, I’m sure.
ERIMEM: But the alarm?
DOCTOR: Like I said, it just went off when the door opened. Nothing else has happened, has it? No bulkheads locking into place, no robot guards scrambling to the scene. Nothing at all. The fact of the matter is there’s no one else here to react to the alarm, is there.
PERI: I guess so.
AUNTIE: That’s the space station, isn’t it?
BUTLER: I’m afraid so, ma’am.
AUNTIE: Is it a fault? Some kind of surge in the circuits?
BUTLER: No, ma’am. It is more serious than that. It would appear there is activity on board the space station. At least three lifeforms.
AUNTIE: It can’t be. Not yet. It’s too soon. We’re not ready.
BUTLER: It is possible that the lifeforms are harmless.
AUNTIE: Harmless? What kind of creature is going to be casually travelling round here? No, I don't like this. I don’t like this at all.
BUTLER: Would you like me to investigate?
AUNTIE: Yes. Port up there immediately.
BUTLER: As you wish, ma’am. Activate medium range transmat system, location Space Station Medusa.
COMPUTER: Medium range transmat. Contact made.
BUTLER: Activate.
AUNTIE: Arm your weapons, Butler. Be prepared.
ERIMEM: Peri, we’ve come a long way inside the station. I know I wanted it dark but isn’t this a bit much?
PERI: And quiet. I wonder what this area was used for?
ERIMEM: It seems even more abandoned than the control room.
PERI: I wonder why that alarm went off? Perhaps it’s a quarantine area.
ERIMEM: The Doctor wouldn’t have let us wander off if there was any danger. At least, I don’t think he would.
PERI: I think this might be a generator room. Where the station’s power comes from.
ERIMEM: What are those shapes piled up over there?
PERI: I don’t know. Could they be eggs?
ERIMEM: If those are eggs, I wouldn’t want to see the chicken that laid them. They’re huge!
PERI: They are eggs, I’m sure of it. How many are there?
ERIMEM: Dozens. No, more than that. Look, they go back further. Piles and piles of them.
PERI: Let me get a closer look.
ERIMEM: Are you sure? It might be dangerous.
PERI: They’re just eggs. They’re not going to start hatching just because I touch them, are they? I just want to see if they're alive.
ERIMEM: Be careful.
LAROQ: How much longer?
COMPUTER: (mostly unintelligible) Sixteen minutes of cardiovascular exercise.
LAROQ: I can’t run any more. Stop the treadmill. (gasping) Thank you. (beep) Bellip, is that you? Did you change your mind? Oh, it’s you.
VIDLER: Who else was it going to be? Still doing your exercises. You obedient little lab rat.
LAROQ: I was bored.
VIDLER: You’re playing into their hands. You been avoiding the food?
LAROQ: Yes, Vidler, I have, and I’m starving. Are you sure it’s necessary?
VIDLER: Of course it is. Don’t you feel the difference?
LAROQ: I feel hungry.
VIDLER: Hungry but alert. I tell you, the food is stuffed with drugs to keep us docile.
LAROQ: Just a minute. The Social’s not due to start yet. How did you manage to port in here?
VIDLER: You see? You're thinking for yourself now.
LAROQ: But how?
VIDLER: Maybe I’m just smarter than the system computer.
LAROQ: What’s that meant to mean? Have you been hacking into central systems again?
VIDLER: Auntie never did prove that.
LAROQ: Vidler, you can’t keep breaking the rules!
VIDLER: Whyever not? If the rules are stupid, they deserve to be broken.
LAROQ: So you’ve hacked the transmat controls.
VIDLER: No, of course not. The system is always open, but most of the sheep in this colony are too timid to try and use the ports any other time.
LAROQ: People are happy in their personal space.
VIDLER: People don’t know what happy is.
LAROQ: And you’re going to change that, are you?
VIDLER: We are. You are still with us, Laroq?
LAROQ: You know I think we should have more freedom.
VIDLER: And this is the way to get it.
LAROQ: How?
VIDLER: By organising. That’s why I wanted us to avoid eating the drugged food. We're having a mass meet.
LAROQ: A what?
VIDLER: I want to get us all together, all the people I’ve been talking to for months. Think of it. It will be historic. The first political rally ever in the history of this planet.
LAROQ: How, how many?
VIDLER: How many what?
LAROQ: How many people?
VIDLER: I don’t know. Five, six? Maybe even eight people.
LAROQ: (panicking) In the same place? In one room?
VIDLER: Imagine it.
LAROQ: I am! Excuse me. I need some space.
VIDLER: It’s nothing to be scared of, Larogq. It’s natural and it’s the future!
COMPUTER: Colonist Bellip Auntie wishes to speak to you one to one.
BELLIP: To me? Okay, accept call.
AUNTIE: [OC]: Colonist Bellip, are you well?
BELLIP: Auntie?
AUNTIE: [OC]: Have you recovered from your illness?
BELLIP: Oh yes, I’m much better now. Much better. In fact, I’ve never been fitter. Are you calling me for any particular reason?
AUNTIE: [OC]: You mean, have I news of the Return selection?
BELLIP: Yes. Have I made it? Am I going home?
AUNTIE: [OC]: I’m sorry, Bellip.
BELLIP: But why? I’ve been eating full rations, completing and exceeding my exercise targets, even when I was ill.
AUNTIE: [OC]: I know. And you are stronger than at your last evaluation, but not strong enough. It'll be too great a risk for you to try a Return today.
BELLIP: But I want to go home. I can’t bear this.
AUNTIE: [OC]: You will return, I promise.
BELLIP: But you could change your mind, couldn’t you?
AUNTIE: [OC]: No. The decision has been made. You will just have to be patient. I am sorry.
PERI: Nothing’s happening. Just eggs.
ERIMEM: Peri, what do you think this is?
PERI: Hmm? Oh, no idea.
ERIMEM: It’s just big enough for me to stand on.
PERI: Careful, you might set something off.
ERIMEM: [OC]: Peri!
PERI: Hold on.
ERIMEM: [OC]: I can’t get out of here. The door’s stuck. I’m trapped.
COMPUTER: The colony was settled in the year 2835, fifty standard years ago.
DOCTOR: Not bad, Doctor. Not bad. Computer, tell me, how many colonists are currently living on the planet?
COMPUTER: Current figures are being collated. Please stand by.
BUTLER: Please stand away from the computers and make yourself known.
DOCTOR: Ah. Company at last. I thought it wouldn’t be long.
BUTLER: Please move away as requested.
DOCTOR: Shall I raise my arms and come quietly?
BUTLER: That would be appreciated.
DOCTOR: Do you have a name or number? I’m the Doctor.
BUTLER: Doctor?
DOCTOR: Just the Doctor. And you’re?
BUTLER: I am designated Butler. Just Butler. No definite article.
DOCTOR: And are you in charge round here?
BUTLER: I am at the service of Auntie. She is the leader of the Earth Colony Phoenix.
DOCTOR: A leader called Auntie, en? How cosy. I don’t suppose you were thinking of taking me to see this Auntie or are you going to throw me into some kind of tedious cell first?
PERI: It’s okay, Erimem, just stay calm. We got that sliding door open earlier, we can do this too.
ERIMEM: [OC]: Quickly, please. I don’t like this.
PERI: Hang on. Must be a way to get it open again.
ERIMEM: [OC]: Peri, this isn’t very pleasant. Hurry.
PERI: There’s some kind of control panel here, but there are no labels or markings.
ERIMEM: [OC]: Try anything! Please, I don’t like this. I feel like I’m trapped in a sarcophagus.
PERI: Okay, okay. Don’t panic. Look, watch me through the window. I’m still here. Let’s see.
ERIMEM: [OC]: Peri!
PERI: Erimem!
DOCTOR: Peri, where’s Erimem? What’s happening?
PERI: She was just in there. But she disappeared in front of my eyes. She just melted away!
DOCTOR: It’s some kind of transmat device. Am I right, Butler?
BUTLER: You are correct, Butler. It is a transmat. This is the station power plant, but the transmat here is connected to the general colony systems.
PERI: Who’s your metal friend?
DOCTOR: This is Butler, and technically we’re his prisoners.
PERI: Oh, terrific.
DOCTOR: But we can deal with all that later. The priority is locating Erimem. Can you trace the port to a destination, Butler?
BUTLER: I am afraid that might not be possible.
PERI: Might not? What do you mean, might not?
BUTLER: The directional controls were scrambled when you attempted to open the transmat pod.
DOCTOR: So it was a random port?
BUTLER: Your friend may have been sent to any one of a thousand port addresses in the colony.
PERI: You still said may. What else may have happened?
BUTLER: If the random coordinates do not relate to an actual port, your friend will never arrive anywhere.
DOCTOR: So she should reappear back here.
BUTLER: No, Doctor. Her atoms will be scattered in space. I fear your friend might already be dead.

elements.text: [Part Two]
There is little we can do from here. Please accompany me to the group teleport terminal, to travel
to the surface.
But what about Erimem?
If I understand this port system correctly, Erimem’s almost certainly already on the surface of the
planet, so following her is probably the optimum course of action right now.
Almost certainly. So you’re not sure?
Now don’t go getting all upset. It really won't help.
Doctor, we can’t keep losing Erimem like this everywhere we go! I can’t deal with it!
I know, Peri, but the best thing we can do is to be positive. Let’s go with Butler here and see what happens. I’m sure we'll find Erimem soon enough, alive and well.
The port’s activating. How can it?
I don’t know, but it is.
What a strange sensation.
It’s a girl.
Bellip, is that you? You changed your mind after all.
Where am I? How did I get here? Where’s Peri?
You just ported here. Don’t you know what you’re doing?
I was on a space station. Something happened.
Space station? You’ve been on Medusa?
Now, Vidler, save it.
But if she’s ported down from Medusa...
(panicking) I’m not interested. She’s here. In my space! With me and you!
Oh, right. Don’t freak out, Laroq.
But there are three people in this room!
I’m sorry, is there a problem?
Too many people. I can’t cope.
Get a grip.
I’m sorry, what’s the matter with him? I don’t understand.
Big brave Larog here has never been in the physical presence of more than one other human being in his entire life. For us, this is a crowded room.
Very efficient transmat system, Butler. I hardly felt a thing.
Speak for yourself. Think I left my stomach on the space station.
The colony relies on the transmat system for all travel.
I thought as much. I imagine that’s the purpose of the space station. Docking facilities up there, then beam down here.
Is this someone’s home? Looks like a small apartment. Bed, gym equipment, kitchenette, living area.
This is a standard habitat cell, currently unoccupied.
Really. Do you have a falling population?
I am sure Auntie will be able to answer all your questions.
I do hope so.
I shall take you to see her now, Doctor, but your companion will have to wait here.
No way. Doctor, I don’t want to be kept out of the loop.
It’s all right, Peri. I’m sure you won’t miss anything. Just wait here, and keep your ears and eyes open. I'll be back soon.
Ready, Doctor?
Whenever you are. Don’t go anywhere, Peri. (transmats)
Where am I going to go? It’s a room with no doors.
That’s it, calm down. Breathe deep and hold, and then exhale.
Is he all right?
Just a panic attack. He'll be fine. But if you wouldn’t mind staying over there, in the port.
Of course, if it will help.
I think I’m okay now. It’s just a shock.
I still can’t believe what you've said. You’ve really never had more than one other person in this room before?
Never.
But why? Are you some kind of special person? A king or god or something?
A god, him? You’ve got to be kidding. You don’t meet living gods, do you?
You'd be surprised.
As a matter of fact, we don’t meet anyone at all if we can help it. We live lives of (ahem) splendid isolation.
I don’t understand. Why?
Because we do.
It’s the way life on this colony has evolved. It’s a necessity of our unfortunate position. We have to focus on preparing to return home.
This colony is a failure, a disaster.
The bottom line is, it’s just not viable. We are the last generation to be born here.
I still don’t understand. How can you have any kind of relationship with anyone if you never meet?
Everything is done by the intercom, usually with the video cameras deactivated.
You don’t even see each other’s faces?
We have become shy.
He means feeble, weak.
We have to focus on the Return.
How many times do I have to tell you, it’s a con, a trick.
It’s not a trick. I know it’s not. Garma has gone, Herol, Magri. They achieved Return status and they went home.
Perhaps.
Why is it so hard for you to go home? Do you not have spaceships?
No. This is a very hostile star system, full of meteorites and planetoids, far from the major space lanes, so we’re dependent on transmat technology. Like the local ports you’ve just travelled in.
I think I prefer doors, and horses, and chariots.
What are horses?
Er, never mind. I still don’t follow why you two haven’t used these transmats to go home.
We have to achieve a certain level of physical fitness to make the journey.
We have a strict routine of diet and exercise to build up the necessary strength in our bodies. That’s why we live in isolation. We cannot allow anything to cloud our focus.
And when you have reached that level, what happens then?
We are tested and then called. Those who are awarded Return status port up to the space station and are placed in stasis. Then they are beamed home.
And they are never heard of again.
Ma’anm,, this is the alien whose craft landed on the space station. He’s called the Doctor.
And why are you here, Doctor? We're a long way from the general space lanes here.
My friends and I are travellers.
Friends?
I travel with two companions, but I’m afraid my spacecraft navigation systems are a little erratic. We don’t always end up where we want to.
That makes sense. No one in his or her right mind comes here willingly. This is a dead-end world in a cul-de-sac star cluster.
An odd choice of location for a colony, if you don’t mind my saying.
The founders wanted independence. They didn’t want Federation officials keeping an eye on them.
Having occasional contact with your home system is one thing. Having none at all is something else. And you don’t have any contact, do you.
Not as such. There is a relay system for long-distance transmats, but it’s become unreliable, like everything around here.
The colony is failing.
The planet wasn’t entirely suitable for habitation when we landed. The terraforming process has
been delayed more than we expected. The development of the new ozone level has taken longer than planned.
But the project will produce results in the end?
But we don’t have time, Doctor. You were right, the colony is failing. It’s ironic. The terraforming is nearly complete, but I fear we’ve run out of time.
I am sorry.
So am I. It’s been a difficult existence since the Retreat. We’ve become insular, withdrawn from each other as much as from the rest of the Federation. We've forgotten what it is to be human.
You have done what you had to do, madam. You have survived.
But at what cost? Any animal will take cover from inclement weather, but when the rain subsides, they have to emerge and get on with living. But us? We’re still cringing in our caves.
I'd like to see if I can help you. Perhaps I can look at ways to strengthen that long-distance transit system of yours.
That would be kind.
But first I need help to locate my missing companion.
You’ve lost one of your crew?
One of the Doctor’s aides was accidentally ported from the Medusa power room. I left the other in an empty habitat cell.
If she’s beamed to this site, the computer can probably locate her. Computer. Initiate a search for the Doctor’s companion on board the colony ship.
Thank you. But what if she’s beamed to one of the other domes?
That is impossible, Doctor. The other domes house...
That’s enough, Butler. Please check on the Doctor’s companion that he has not mislaid, will you? See that she has access to food and drink.
Of course, ma’am. (transmats)
A very loyal droid you have there, Auntie.
Without Butler, and the other servitors, I don’t know how we would have survived this long. Now then, Doctor. Let’s see what our computers can do for you.
Ah, there you are. How long am I going to have to wait here? And where’s the Doctor?
I have been asked to make sure you have access to refreshments.
That'd be nice. I’m starving. But do you think you could answer my questions?
I cannot tell you how long you will have to wait. Auntie is assisting the Doctor to locate your missing friend.
Erimem’s alive?
As yet we cannot be sure.
Terrific. So I just have to kick my heels after all, I guess.
Such activity will result in bruising, Miss Peri.
Was that meant to be a joke?
I am not programmed for humour.
My mum had the same problem. So, where are all the people on this planet?
What people are you referring to?
When we were in space, there looked like about a dozen domes down here. There must be thousand and thousands of people running about, so, where’s the action? Do you have shops?
You have made a false assumption, Miss Peri. The colony is not as large as it appears. The number of colonists active on the planet at the moment is tiny.
Couple of hundred?
Sixteen.
Sixteen hundred?
Sixteen individuals.
I cannot believe that you are happy to live this way.
Listen to her, Laroq. She’s talking sense.
She’s as mad as you are, you mean.
But can’t you see that this isn’t natural? You’re human beings. We're social creatures, not hermits.
We can’t move around except by port, and the computer monitors our every movement.
There must be another way out of this room.
Can you see one?
There is only the one door.
To the bathroom. No exit through there.

There must be something. When my people built the pyramids, the engineers constructed hidden doors and passages. It looked as if the resting places of the Pharaohs had no exits, but it was an illusion.
You think there might be a hidden exit to one of these cells?
Have you ever looked for one?
No, I’ve never thought... Come on, Larog, and check that wall.
Tap the walls and listen. Here. This sounds hollow. Do you not agree?
It does sound different.
Help me move this furniture.
Hey, be careful.
If you tried helping rather than moaning, you might prevent it getting damaged.
Okay, okay.
A little further. All right. Ah, look.
Incredible!
What is it?
What are you, children? That is a door.
Sound of crying.
Hello? Who’s there? Where’s it coming from? Over here. Hello? Can you hear me?
[OC]: Who is that?
My name’s Peri. And you?
[OC]: I’m Bellip.
Are you a prisoner too, Bellip?
[OC]: A prisoner?
Well, trapped, like I am. There’s no door in here.
[OC]: There’s the port.
I don’t Know how to use it.
[OC]: It’s a port. You just dial a destination code and hit the activation control.
I don’t Know any destination codes.
[OC]: You don’t?
What's your code?
Right. Here goes nothing.
Nothing yet from your computer?
I’m sorry, Doctor. You'll have to forgive us. Our technology is not all it should be.
Perhaps I can take a look at your systems for you. I have some experience with advanced computers.
That won't be necessary.
In that case, maybe I should check in on Peri. If you can just point me in the right direction?
Allow me, Doctor.
Ah, Butler. I didn’t notice you were back. How is Peri?
I left her some refreshments. Would you care to join her?
Please.
Step onto the transmat and I will operate it for you. Ready?
Whenever you are. (transmat)
The Doctor asks too many questions.
He is an unknown factor, ma’am. He might make things difficult for you.
I know. Why did he have to arrive now? I can’t believe it’s a coincidence.
You think he is an agent for another party?
I don’t know. I just know he’s a complication I could do without.
I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to freak you out.
(hyperventilating) It’s not your fault. I’m not good with seeing people.
You live here alone?
We all live alone. That’s how we are.
Don’t you have friends?
Not really. There are people I speak to on the channels, and then there’s Laroq.
Who is Laroq?
A boy I speak to. I want to see him, but I can’t.
Can’t?
I can’t cope with being in the same room as someone else. It makes me feel ill.
Wow. And I thought my teenage angst years were bad.
Who are you, Peri? Where have you come from?
I'm a traveller. I come from a world where humans live with each other, sometimes in great numbers. And believe me, it is possible.
It sounds horrible.
It’s not so bad. Look, can I get off this pad? I'll keep my distance, I promise you.
Okay.
Breathe deeply. Slowly.
Right.
Don’t panic. That’s it. Okay so far?
Yes, I, I think so.
Why don’t I sit over here. Not too close, is it?
No. It’s okay.
Right then. Well, this is nice, isn’t it?
I, I suppose.
Maybe you were mistaken. It can’t be a door.
Of course it is.
Then why can’t we open it?
It must be locked somehow.
Because we’re not meant to use it.
Find something to hit it with.
One of the exercise weights.
Hey, don’t damage them.
It’s the door we want to damage, not the weights. Try here, where the gap is.
It moved.
Again.
I think I can get my hand in the gap.
Pull it. It’s opening! It was just stuck.
Where does it lead?
A corridor.
What?
A passageway, with lots more of these doors leading off.
It’s like a room with no end.
I wonder where it leads?
I can’t believe you’ve never seen the sky.
I’ve hardly ever been outside this room in my entire life.
But that’s so sad.
That’s all I’ve ever known. What is it like, outside?
I don’t know where to start. It’s just open. You can feel the wind on your face, see for miles.
Sounds frightening.
But it’s not. It’s just what you’re used to, I guess.
I don’t think I'd like it.
You shouldn’t knock it until you’ve tried it. Living like this, locked up inside this room, it can’t be much fun.
I’m happy like this.
Are you? Really?
Yes.
But you were interested in this boy Laroq.
He has a gentle voice.
And you would like to hear it more?
Yes.
You'd like to spend more time talking to him, maybe some time with him?
Yes.
So, you do want more. The desire is there inside. You've just been brainwashed into thinking this is normal. Who's responsible for all this? Auntie?
Auntie is our leader. She looks after us.
By shutting you up in cages?
We have to be strong. We have to grow, eat our supplements, build up our body mass. We have to be fit to make the journey home.
Even athletes in training get breaks. Haven't you heard of life — work balance?
Thank you for visiting, Peri, but I think I’d like to be alone now.
You want me to go, just like that?
I need to be alone.
What you need is to get out of here and get a life.
Please.
Okay, okay, I’m going.
Just hit the blue return switch and you'll go directly back to the habitat cell you came from.
This isn’t natural, Bellip. I think you should meet the Doctor. He’ll know what to do about all this. He can help you, I’m sure. (transmat)
I’m sorry, Peri. I need my space.
Ah, there you are, Peri. I was beginning to get worried.
I heard crying from the cell next door.
And you managed to teleport in to investigate?
It was a girl named Bellip. She told me her destination code and I just punched it into the control panel. It was as easy as stepping through a door.
That’s just the problem with teleport systems. Instantaneous travel between different places is too easy. Makes people lazy.
And it seems to make them passive as well. Bellip told me she’s hardly ever left her room in her entire life.
That doesn’t sound healthy, does it?
It’s just weird, if you ask me. I don’t like it, Doctor. It’s like some kind of lunatic asylum. What’s going on here?
I don’t know yet, but you’re right, something is very wrong here.
Doctor, on the space station, Erimem and I found a load of eggs.
What kind of eggs?
Big ones, about a foot wide. There were hundreds of them in what I think was the station’s generator room.
Something else that sounds like it warrants investigation.
So, where do we start?
We start by avoiding the teleports.
Well, that won’t get us a long way. There aren’t any doors, or hadn’t you noticed?
Where there’s a will, Peri. Now then, let’s check these walls. If I’m right, and I usually am, this should be the right place to look. Ah!
Steady on, Doctor. No need to wreck the joint.
Just a little redecoration. Didn’t you think it odd to hang a rug on the wall like that?
I thought it was a quirk of interior design.
Whereas it was actually hiding a door. There had to be one.
Can you open it?
It’s a bit stiff but... there you are. Ladies first.
Oh, thanks.
Why am I awake? Is it time?
It is my time.
Your Majesty, I am, as ever, your servant.
I have laid my last egg. My death will come soon.
No, your Majesty, please.
Be silent, General. I have little time. You and your guardsmen must complete your task and protect the brood.
With our lives.
I expect no less. The future of the Khellian race depends on it.
My men and I have been hibernating for some time. We will need nourishment.
Feast as you require, but do not risk the safety of the brood. The future must be protected.
A corridor. Well, this is a surprise.
Come on, Peri, use your powers of observation. What do you see?
I told you, I see a corridor.
And?
Doors like the ones we’ve just come through.
What else?
The wall’s a slight curve and the corridor has a slight bend to it.
Reminiscent of?
I don’t know. It could be a... Oh, you think this is a spaceship.
I’m beginning to suspect this is the original colony ship, lying on the planet. I wonder why they’re not using the domes?
This must be the door that leads to Bellip’s room. It’s numbered 478, the same as her transmat destination code.
That simplifies things.
Can we open this door from this side?
I think so. Can you remember what was on the other side of her room?
Another one of those depressing rugs, I think.
Scrape.
Bellip? That’s better. Bellip?
No one home?
She’s gone. I wonder where?
You must have scared her witless with your tales of the outside.
I was trying to help.
She may still need your help.
Why don’t I follow her? If I understand this thing correctly, I can just port to wherever it is she’s just travelled to.
And I'll pop back to the space station. Maybe I'll be able to track her from there. I wouldn’t mind having a look at those eggs of yours either.
Doctor, do you think we’re in danger here?
I don’t know what to think yet, but to be on the safe side, don’t trust anyone.
Okay. If you say so.
It goes on and on. This is amazing!
It might be for you. It’s making my head hurt.
If it becomes too much, look down at your feet as you walk.
Thank you. I'll try that.
What are the numbers on these doors?
Looks like they’re room numbers. And they seem to match the port codes we use.
243. Wasn’t that Ragir’s code?
Yeah. This must be his habitat cell.
Who is Raaqir?
One of Vidler’s rebels.
One of the first. Or at least, he was. We haven't heard from him for weeks, and his port code has been closed down.
Maybe he’s been ill or something.
Are you worried about him?
Of course.
Then we should investigate. I’m sure we can get this door open.
Scraping.
Oh, it stinks in here.
Stale air.
Ragir? Are you in here?
No sign of him. But look at this place. No one’s been in here for weeks.
I wonder where he went?
He wasn’t due to make the Return, was he?
He never said.
The last pod destination is still in the memory chip. We could see where his last journey took him.
One of us...
He was your ally.
I don’t know.
Are you both cowards?
It’s not that, but, well, wherever he went, he never came back, did he.
I will go. Just show me what to do to get back.

I suppose I should be grateful they maintain atmosphere up here. Slightly stale air, recycled a million times, but beggars can’t be choosers. Wonder what this is. An impressive looking door, certainly. Maybe a vault, Doctor. What do you say? (door opens) It’s like a cold storage facility, with its own teleport terminal. Interesting.
Teleport activates.
Doctor!
Erimem. How splendid. I was beginning to worry about you. Here, let me help you up.
What is this place?
I’m not quite sure yet. Some kind of cryogenic store, I think.
And what's in these drawers?
Oh dear. We don’t want to be looking at something like that, do we.
What has happened to the rest of him?
I think he’d been eaten.
That’s sick!
I’ve suddenly got a very bad feeling about this place.
Is it a House of the Dead? Will the restless spirits rise?
No. No, it’s not a morgue.
It certainly is not.
What? Doctor, what is that?
I am General Makra’Thon of the Khellian Royal Guard, and this? This is my larder.
