BELLIP: [OC]: There’s the port.
PERI: I don’t Know how to use it.
BELLIP: [OC]: It’s a port. You just dial a destination code and hit the activation control.
PERI: I don’t Know any destination codes.
BELLIP: [OC]: You don’t?
PERI: What's your code?
BELLIP: [OC]: 478.
PERI: Right. Here goes nothing.
DOCTOR: Nothing yet from your computer?
AUNTIE: I’m sorry, Doctor. You'll have to forgive us. Our technology is not all it should be.
DOCTOR: Perhaps I can take a look at your systems for you. I have some experience with advanced computers.
AUNTIE: That won't be necessary.
DOCTOR: In that case, maybe I should check in on Peri. If you can just point me in the right direction?
BUTLER: Allow me, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Ah, Butler. I didn’t notice you were back. How is Peri?
BUTLER: I left her some refreshments. Would you care to join her?
DOCTOR: Please.
BUTLER: Step onto the transmat and I will operate it for you. Ready?
DOCTOR: Whenever you are. (transmat)
AUNTIE: The Doctor asks too many questions.
BUTLER: He is an unknown factor, ma’am. He might make things difficult for you.
AUNTIE: I know. Why did he have to arrive now? I can’t believe it’s a coincidence.
BUTLER: You think he is an agent for another party?
AUNTIE: I don’t know. I just know he’s a complication I could do without.
PERI: I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to freak you out.
BELLIP: (hyperventilating) It’s not your fault. I’m not good with seeing people.
PERI: You live here alone?
BELLIP: We all live alone. That’s how we are.
PERI: Don’t you have friends?
BELLIP: Not really. There are people I speak to on the channels, and then there’s Laroq.
PERI: Who is Laroq?
BELLIP: A boy I speak to. I want to see him, but I can’t.
PERI: Can’t?
BELLIP: I can’t cope with being in the same room as someone else. It makes me feel ill.
PERI: Wow. And I thought my teenage angst years were bad.
BELLIP: Who are you, Peri? Where have you come from?
PERI: I'm a traveller. I come from a world where humans live with each other, sometimes in great numbers. And believe me, it is possible.
BELLIP: It sounds horrible.
PERI: It’s not so bad. Look, can I get off this pad? I'll keep my distance, I promise you.
BELLIP: Okay.
PERI: Breathe deeply. Slowly.
BELLIP: Right.
PERI: Don’t panic. That’s it. Okay so far?
BELLIP: Yes, I, I think so.
PERI: Why don’t I sit over here. Not too close, is it?
BELLIP: No. It’s okay.
PERI: Right then. Well, this is nice, isn’t it?
BELLIP: I, I suppose.
VIDLER: Maybe you were mistaken. It can’t be a door.
ERIMEM: Of course it is.
VIDLER: Then why can’t we open it?
ERIMEM: It must be locked somehow.
LAROQ: Because we’re not meant to use it.
ERIMEM: Find something to hit it with.
VIDLER: One of the exercise weights.
LAROQ: Hey, don’t damage them.
ERIMEM: It’s the door we want to damage, not the weights. Try here, where the gap is.
VIDLER: It moved.
ERIMEM: Again.
VIDLER: I think I can get my hand in the gap.
ERIMEM: Pull it. It’s opening! It was just stuck.
LAROQ: Where does it lead?
ERIMEM: A corridor.
LAROQ: What?
ERIMEM: A passageway, with lots more of these doors leading off.
LAROQ: It’s like a room with no end.
ERIMEM: I wonder where it leads?
PERI: I can’t believe you’ve never seen the sky.
BELLIP: I’ve hardly ever been outside this room in my entire life.
PERI: But that’s so sad.
BELLIP: That’s all I’ve ever known. What is it like, outside?
PERI: I don’t know where to start. It’s just open. You can feel the wind on your face, see for miles.
BELLIP: Sounds frightening.
PERI: But it’s not. It’s just what you’re used to, I guess.
BELLIP: I don’t think I'd like it.
PERI: You shouldn’t knock it until you’ve tried it. Living like this, locked up inside this room, it can’t be much fun.
BELLIP: I’m happy like this.
PERI: Are you? Really?
BELLIP: Yes.
PERI: But you were interested in this boy Laroq.
BELLIP: He has a gentle voice.
PERI: And you would like to hear it more?
BELLIP: Yes.
PERI: You'd like to spend more time talking to him, maybe some time with him?
BELLIP: Yes.
PERI: So, you do want more. The desire is there inside. You've just been brainwashed into thinking this is normal. Who's responsible for all this? Auntie?
BELLIP: Auntie is our leader. She looks after us.
PERI: By shutting you up in cages?
BELLIP: We have to be strong. We have to grow, eat our supplements, build up our body mass. We have to be fit to make the journey home.
PERI: Even athletes in training get breaks. Haven't you heard of life — work balance?
BELLIP: Thank you for visiting, Peri, but I think I’d like to be alone now.
PERI: You want me to go, just like that?
BELLIP: I need to be alone.
PERI: What you need is to get out of here and get a life.
BELLIP: Please.
PERI: Okay, okay, I’m going.
BELLIP: Just hit the blue return switch and you'll go directly back to the habitat cell you came from.
PERI: This isn’t natural, Bellip. I think you should meet the Doctor. He’ll know what to do about all this. He can help you, I’m sure. (transmat)
BELLIP: I’m sorry, Peri. I need my space.
DOCTOR: Ah, there you are, Peri. I was beginning to get worried.
PERI: I heard crying from the cell next door.
DOCTOR: And you managed to teleport in to investigate?
PERI: It was a girl named Bellip. She told me her destination code and I just punched it into the control panel. It was as easy as stepping through a door.
DOCTOR: That’s just the problem with teleport systems. Instantaneous travel between different places is too easy. Makes people lazy.
PERI: And it seems to make them passive as well. Bellip told me she’s hardly ever left her room in her entire life.
DOCTOR: That doesn’t sound healthy, does it?
PERI: It’s just weird, if you ask me. I don’t like it, Doctor. It’s like some kind of lunatic asylum. What’s going on here?
DOCTOR: I don’t know yet, but you’re right, something is very wrong here.
PERI: Doctor, on the space station, Erimem and I found a load of eggs.
DOCTOR: What kind of eggs?
PERI: Big ones, about a foot wide. There were hundreds of them in what I think was the station’s generator room.
DOCTOR: Something else that sounds like it warrants investigation.
PERI: So, where do we start?
DOCTOR: We start by avoiding the teleports.
PERI: Well, that won’t get us a long way. There aren’t any doors, or hadn’t you noticed?
DOCTOR: Where there’s a will, Peri. Now then, let’s check these walls. If I’m right, and I usually am, this should be the right place to look. Ah!
PERI: Steady on, Doctor. No need to wreck the joint.
DOCTOR: Just a little redecoration. Didn’t you think it odd to hang a rug on the wall like that?
PERI: I thought it was a quirk of interior design.
DOCTOR: Whereas it was actually hiding a door. There had to be one.
PERI: Can you open it?
DOCTOR: It’s a bit stiff but... there you are. Ladies first.
PERI: Oh, thanks.
GENERAL: Why am I awake? Is it time?
QUEEN: It is my time.
GENERAL: Your Majesty, I am, as ever, your servant.
QUEEN: I have laid my last egg. My death will come soon.
GENERAL: No, your Majesty, please.
QUEEN: Be silent, General. I have little time. You and your guardsmen must complete your task and protect the brood.
GENERAL: With our lives.
QUEEN: I expect no less. The future of the Khellian race depends on it.
GENERAL: My men and I have been hibernating for some time. We will need nourishment.
QUEEN: Feast as you require, but do not risk the safety of the brood. The future must be protected.
PERI: A corridor. Well, this is a surprise.
DOCTOR: Come on, Peri, use your powers of observation. What do you see?
PERI: I told you, I see a corridor.
DOCTOR: And?
PERI: Doors like the ones we’ve just come through.
DOCTOR: What else?
PERI: The wall’s a slight curve and the corridor has a slight bend to it.
DOCTOR: Reminiscent of?
PERI: I don’t know. It could be a... Oh, you think this is a spaceship.
DOCTOR: I’m beginning to suspect this is the original colony ship, lying on the planet. I wonder why they’re not using the domes?
PERI: This must be the door that leads to Bellip’s room. It’s numbered 478, the same as her transmat destination code.
DOCTOR: That simplifies things.
PERI: Can we open this door from this side?
DOCTOR: I think so. Can you remember what was on the other side of her room?
PERI: Another one of those depressing rugs, I think.
PERI: Bellip? That’s better. Bellip?
DOCTOR: No one home?
PERI: She’s gone. I wonder where?
DOCTOR: You must have scared her witless with your tales of the outside.
PERI: I was trying to help.
DOCTOR: She may still need your help.
PERI: Why don’t I follow her? If I understand this thing correctly, I can just port to wherever it is she’s just travelled to.
DOCTOR: And I'll pop back to the space station. Maybe I'll be able to track her from there. I wouldn’t mind having a look at those eggs of yours either.
PERI: Doctor, do you think we’re in danger here?
DOCTOR: I don’t know what to think yet, but to be on the safe side, don’t trust anyone.
PERI: Okay. If you say so.
VIDLER: It goes on and on. This is amazing!
LAROQ: It might be for you. It’s making my head hurt.
ERIMEM: If it becomes too much, look down at your feet as you walk.
LAROQ: Thank you. I'll try that.
ERIMEM: What are the numbers on these doors?
VIDLER: Looks like they’re room numbers. And they seem to match the port codes we use.
LAROQ: 243. Wasn’t that Ragir’s code?
VIDLER: Yeah. This must be his habitat cell.
ERIMEM: Who is Raaqir?
LAROQ: One of Vidler’s rebels.
VIDLER: One of the first. Or at least, he was. We haven't heard from him for weeks, and his port code has been closed down.
LAROQ: Maybe he’s been ill or something.
ERIMEM: Are you worried about him?
VIDLER: Of course.
ERIMEM: Then we should investigate. I’m sure we can get this door open.
LAROQ: Oh, it stinks in here.
ERIMEM: Stale air.
VIDLER: Ragir? Are you in here?
LAROQ: No sign of him. But look at this place. No one’s been in here for weeks.
VIDLER: I wonder where he went?
LAROQ: He wasn’t due to make the Return, was he?
VIDLER: He never said.
LAROQ: The last pod destination is still in the memory chip. We could see where his last journey took him.
VIDLER: One of us...
LAROQ: He was your ally.
VIDLER: I don’t know.
ERIMEM: Are you both cowards?
VIDLER: It’s not that, but, well, wherever he went, he never came back, did he.
ERIMEM: I will go. Just show me what to do to get back.
DOCTOR: I suppose I should be grateful they maintain atmosphere up here. Slightly stale air, recycled a million times, but beggars can’t be choosers. Wonder what this is. An impressive looking door, certainly. Maybe a vault, Doctor. What do you say? (door opens) It’s like a cold storage facility, with its own teleport terminal. Interesting.
ERIMEM: Doctor!
DOCTOR: Erimem. How splendid. I was beginning to worry about you. Here, let me help you up.
ERIMEM: What is this place?
DOCTOR: I’m not quite sure yet. Some kind of cryogenic store, I think.
ERIMEM: And what's in these drawers?
DOCTOR: Oh dear. We don’t want to be looking at something like that, do we.
ERIMEM: What has happened to the rest of him?
DOCTOR: I think he’d been eaten.
ERIMEM: That’s sick!
DOCTOR: I’ve suddenly got a very bad feeling about this place.
ERIMEM: Is it a House of the Dead? Will the restless spirits rise?
DOCTOR: No. No, it’s not a morgue.
GENERAL: It certainly is not.
ERIMEM: What? Doctor, what is that?
GENERAL: I am General Makra’Thon of the Khellian Royal Guard, and this? This is my larder.

elements.text: [Part Three]
Larder?
Larder, food store, pantry. I was hoping to get a bite to eat. Frozen would have been fine, but fresh meat is so much tastier.
Fresh meat? Does this creature want to eat us?
Just one of you will suffice for now. No need to be greedy.
No, no!
Erimem...
Weapons fire, Erimem screams.
General! There was no need for violence.
You saw the girl run from me.
She was trying to escape!
There is no escape from the Khellian Royal Guard.
Bellip is weeping. Teleport.
That doesn’t get any better. The Doctor was lying. Bellip? Are you here?
Too big. I can’t deal with it.
Bellip, where are you? What is this place, some kind of lecture room?
I don’t know. It’s so large.
Oh, there you are. What are you doing under that desk?
I needed somewhere to hide.
From what?
I don’t know. After you left me, I was just filled with panic, so I dialled a random. I just wanted to get away, and I came here, and it’s so big!
It’s just a small hall.
It’s the biggest space I’ve ever been in. So big.
Bellip, don’t panic. Get a grip.
I can’t. It’s too much.

Bellip! Breathe like you did before. Slowly. Hold it in. That’s it. Then breathe out. That’s it. Just calm down. You're in control. You’re perfectly safe. You’re still inside. There’s a roof above you, and four walls around you.
(calmer) I’m sorry. You must think I’m an idiot.
It’s not your fault. It’s the way you’ve been brought up. You mustn’t feel bad.

Oh, but I do. You talked about the outside, about being in the open, but I can’t even enter a large room without having a panic attack. So how will I ever cope when I make the Return? Maybe that’s why I’ve never been chosen.
She should have been back by now.
How long has it been?
I don’t know. Five minutes? Ten? What's it matter? She was just going to port in and port back again to tell us where she went. Maybe she found something there she wasn’t expecting.
Like what?
I don’t know, do I?
Go after her, then.
What?
You want to do things, be proactive, don’t you? You’re always telling me that we’re too passive. So act. Do something. Follow Erimem. Find out what’s happened to her.
And leave you alone?
I'll cope. I might even prefer it.
I think we should wait a little longer.
Maybe she fainted in transit. Well, she’s not used to porting, is she?
In which case she’s probably in a heap on the port dais. I could use the recall.
Are you sure?
Okay, here goes.
Oh, nothing.
She must have stepped off the platform.
Or been taken off.
We can't stay here. If the Servitors catch us, we'll never get another chance like this to explore.
No. No, we should wait for Erimem.
You were just telling me to do something. We have to seize our chance. We might never get another opportunity like this. Make a mental note of the setting. We can always try and find her later.
You want to go back into the corridor?
I want to see where it goes. Are you coming?
I don’t know. No. Vid. Vidler! Wait, I’m coming! Don’t leave me.
Erimem. She’s still breathing, thank goodness.
Step away from the female.
What have you done to her? There was no call for that.
She was attempting to escape. Besides, it was a non-fatal charge. She will recover consciousness, eventually.
You shot her in the back. What kind of soldier are you?
A hungry one. You’re not one of the colonists. Who are you?
I’m the Doctor. I travel.
Really. How unfortunate for you.
I’ve some things on my travels, some amazing sights, but I’ve rarely come across something as foul as I’ve discovered here.
And what is that, Doctor?
You’ve turned this colony into some kind of farm, haven’t you?
Everyone has to eat.
These colonists are sentient beings.
Meat is meat.
No! How can any civilised creature eat something with which he’s just had a conversation?
As a rule, I don’t. I was always brought up not to play with my food.
Erimem groans.
How long has this been going on?
That’s not your concern.
I will not allow this to continue.
And who are you to stop a troop of trained warriors? Will you talk us into submission?
I'll find a way.
I doubt that. You have no idea what you are dealing with, do you?
Don’t I? The Khellian race. I’m sure I’ve heard of you. Let’s see. Brutal, militaristic, aggressive. Is that you?
How about respected, successful, all-conquering.
It’s all a question of perspective.
The strong survive. The weak fall. It is the way of nature. We are all creatures on the food chain.
And you think you’re at the top of that chain.
Well, of course. What else is there?
Me.
The General laughs.
Am I meant to be frightened of you just because you’ve got a gun?
You think I’m a fool. Are you expecting me to throw away my weapon to provide a level playing field?
It might be nice.
Khellians are not fools.
No, I can see that, but you have your weaknesses. Every creature has its Achilles heel.
Khellians have no weaknesses, only strengths.
What kind of creatures are you? Reptilian, cold-blooded, air-breathing. So, not particularly at home in deep space.
Khellians have developed survival suits for alien environments.
But Khellians are still humanoid in form, so you have the same weak spots as us. The throat, the belly, the back of the neck.
The General gurgles.
Well done, Erimem. I hoped you were listening.
Is it dead?
Just stunned.
What is it?
I'll explain later. We'd better get away from here before he recovers.
Alarms sounding.
I don’t understand, Butler. What’s going on?
It appears that someone has accessed the forbidden zones inside the colony ship.
Aliens or colonists?
It is possible that it is the Doctor and his friend. They are no longer in the holding cell.
Then find them.
There has also been one transport to the space station, but just the one.
Run a check on all habitat cells. Make sure it’s only the Doctor and his companions we have to worry about.
As you command.
After all this time. We cannot afford for things to go wrong now. Not now.
All the colonists who are due to Return today are prepared.
Thank goodness for that. And the rest?
Three colonists are unaccounted for.
And some of them are loose in the forbidden areas of the ship?
Apparently.
Terrific. Can you identify them?
The missing colonists are 256 Laroq. 147 Vidler, and 478 Bellip.
Bellip? No.
I am sorry, ma’am.
Sorry won't do. I need action. Activate more servitors. Find those children now, before it’s too late.
As you wish.
Your priority is Bellip. Bring the boys back dead or alive, but make sure Bellip is unharmed. Understand?
Yes, ma’am.
How are you doing now?
Oh, I’m feeling a little better.
Can you move any faster?
Oh, I don’t know about that. One step at a time, you said.
I know what I said. I was kinda hoping you might do it a little quicker than that. It’s like walking with my old granny.
Your what?
My grandmother. My mother’s mother?
I don’t even know my mother.
You don’t?
I was brought up by Servitors.
Robots like Butler?
Yes.
But you must have had a mother.
I’ve never thought about it. We don’t think about it.
Look around you. This is some kind of meeting room. You colonists didn’t always live like this in isolation. You must have been normal social creatures once.
Not in my time.
But if your people lived like that before, they can do it again.
(gasp) Live among other people? Sharing spaces? Oh, I don’t know. That makes me feel ill. It’s too much. I can’t.
Oh, come on, Bellip. Don’t lose it now.
The things you’re saying. You’re filling my head with things I can’t deal with.
Remember the breathing exercises. Close your eyes and concentrate on breathing. That’s it. And hold it. Five, six, seven, eight, and let it out slowly.
Okay. I think I’m okay.
Let’s move out then. Are you up for that?
I’ll try, but you'll have to be patient with me.
Come on. This way.
Where is this going, Vidler?
I’ve no idea, but I want to find out.
Where is everyone? I thought there were thousands of colonists, but all these cells are empty.
Perhaps they’ve been lying to us all this time. How many other colonists do you know?
You, Bellip. Er, I saw a medic once years ago. There was Raagir. I’ve spoken to someone called Lakkar. Er, another boy called Jobie. Who else?
Apart from Auntie, of course. Well, there’s the other rebels, Raqir, Garma and Magri.
You said there were eight of us.
I may have exaggerated.
So, between us, we only know a handful of people.
There must be more. There must be.
Perhaps more people have Returned than we’ve been told.
Or maybe they haven't.
Where now?
This way. I want to put as much distance between us and the General as possible.
When I first saw him, I thought it was Sobek.
Sobek? One of your fellow gods, isn’t he? Head of a crocodile, body of a man. That’s the fellow, right?
God of the Nile. But it wasn’t him, was it?
No, the General is from an alien reptilian race called the Khellians, and I doubt he‘s here alone.
The eggs Peri and I found, are they...

Khellian eggs, almost certainly. I’m trying to remember what I know about their life cycle. They have a Queen who produces thousands of eggs at a time, then dies. Until the eggs hatch, the Khellians are in a vulnerable state. The Queen’s Royal Guard must protect the brood at all costs.
What do they want with the colonists?
It’s simple. They've clearly been using the colony as some kind of farm. I fear it’s time for a harvest.
That’s horrible. Can we stop them?

I certainly intend to try. We need to warn Auntie about the presence of these aliens and the threat they pose, but we also need to know where the aliens are and in what numbers. Can you lead me to the area where you found the eggs?
I think so.
Lead on, then, Erimem. Lead on.
Another corridor.
Oh, I don’t mind. The way they curve, I can pretend it’s just a long room.
In that case, can we move a little faster then?
Oh, I’m trying, Peri. I really am.
Stop.
What is it?
I heard something up ahead. Quick, up against the wall.
(sotto) I can’t hear anything.
(sotto) Feel the floor. Vibrations. There’s someone coming.
(sotto) Someone? Who?
It just doesn’t make sense. There must be someone else here somewhere.
Look!
Don’t run.
Who are you?
I’m Peri, and this is Bellip.
Bellip. Oh, it’s me, Laroq.
Laroq? Ah!
She’s fainted! Do one of you two lads think you could possible lend a hand? She’s heavier than she looks and I don’t want to drop her.
You’re touching her.
Just trying to support her. It’s not a crime.
Here, let me.
Thank you. Lay her down a moment. I’m sure she'll be okay in a minute or two. The shock of being with three other people was just too much for her.
I know how she feels.
It’s okay, Laroq. You can do this. It’s mind over matter.
Whispering
There you are.
Just two of the General’s guards. Good.
What is that thing at the back?
That is the Khellian Queen. She’s dying.
Should we attack?
No.
Do you think there are any more of them?
There will be if those eggs hatch. They’ve turned the space station’s power generator into a nursery, using heat to mature the brood.
But when the eggs hatch, the colony will be overrun. We should destroy the station and destroy the brood.
You must be feeling better. That sounds like the Erimem I first met, the warrior Queen.
I’m just being practical.
Door opens and closes. Speaking normally and walking.
Why did we not see those guards earlier, when Peri and I first found the eggs.

Hibernation. The Khellians hibernate for long periods. The last brood have died out, leaving this Queen and a handful of guards to seed the next one. Once the Queen woke to lay the eggs, the remaining guards come out of hibernation to protect them.
Meanwhile the Queen dies?
She’s done her job. Well, not all of it. There’s one last task she has, even in death.
Huh?
Let’s not think about that. Ah, here we are. Back to the central control.
What are you doing now?
Scanning the colony ship. I want to find Peri.
Where is she?
I left her exploring. Oh, that’s interesting.
What does it mean?
A number of human lifesigns wandering aimlessly around the corridors. Three, maybe four. Gamma deck.
Could one be Peri?

What do you think? Now, I need to talk to Auntie. Will you be okay waiting here? I want you to keep an eye on the Khellians. If they start to move, let me know. Take refuge in the Tardis if you have to. You have a key, don’t you?
Round my neck, as usual. Good luck then.
And to you. Brave heart, Erimem.
Your Majesty? You summoned me.
It is time. Do not fail us.

Your Majesty. The Queen has died. Now our only hope is the hatchlings she has left us to protect. You two, move the Queen’s corpse into the middle of the room. The first thing the new generation sees will be their mother. Quiet. It begins. The hatching will soon start. When it does, the hatchlings will need fresh meat. We cannot wait for the next delivery of Returnees. We shall go directly to the source. They shall need sustenance for the days ahead. Soldiers, prepare for a hunt. We can transport together from the main control room.
Doctor, where have you been?
Auntie, sorry about that. I needed to do a bit of exploring.
In the forbidden zones?
I wanted to talk to you about that. You’ve made most of the colony ship out of bounds. Why?
It was necessary. We need to keep order.
To keep control, you mean. Actually, I’ve been back to your space station. You’ve got some unwanted guests up there, you know.
It must be the day for unwanted guests. Where is your companion, Peri?
She’s on gamma deck, sector 16. She appears to be with some of your people.
Our missing colonists. Thank you, Doctor. You’ve been very helpful. Butler, the children are in sector 16 on gamma deck.
BUTLER [OC]: Understood, ma’am.
How quickly can you get there?
BUTLER [OC]: I can port there in seconds, ma’am.
Do it.
There’s something else I need to talk to you about.
Which is?
The alien presence on the space station.
More visitors. How unusual. Are you sure?
I’ve seen them with my own eyes, and had a run-in with one of their number. And they’re not visitors, they’re squatters.
Squatters?
You must warn your people. As far as I can tell, they've just woken up from a deep sleep and they could begin porting down here at any moment.
And what do these aliens want?
Food. And you and your colonists are on the menu.
Come on, Doctor. Hurry up. I think I’ve got company.
Come on. The sooner we get down to the colony, the sooner we can sate our appetites. Assemble on the terminal. Activate the transfer. (transmat)
They’ve gone. All of them.
Bellip? Bellip, can you hear me?
Oh. Where?
It’s okay, you’re safe.
Oh, I’m sorry. It was such a shock. I am sorry, Laroq. I had no idea what you looked like.
I hope you weren’t disappointed.
No, not at all.
If you don’t mind, can we do the teen romance stuff later?
I thought that Erimem was one of a kind, but maybe I was wrong.
You’ve seen Erimem?
She ported into my cell, uninvited.
It was Erimem who showed us how to get into these corridors. We were exploring with her...
So where is she now?
She went to see where our friend Ragir last travelled to.
But she didn’t come back? Why didn’t you go after her?
We, we er...
We didn’t know if it was wise.
So you just left her? Pathetic.
There’s a port over here just activating.
(panic) More people?
Quick, take cover.
It looks like a Servitor.
Laroq, take Bellip into a cell and stay there until you hear from me.
Right.
Vidler and I will try and draw it away.
We will?
Come on!
Miss Peri, please stop.
Sorry, gotta run.
I am authorised to use offensive weaponry.
Isn’t all weaponry offensive?
Only if you’re at the wrong end of it.
Is he following us?
Yes, I think he is.
Weapons fire.
I think the plan’s working then.
So far. Why have you stopped?
Shh. Look up ahead.
What’s that?
It looks to me like some kind of uniformed reptile.
An alien?
Give the man a cigar.
Is that some kind of weapon?
Another cigar, please.
Weapons fire.
In here, now.
Door opens and closes.
I wonder whose cell this was?
Listen. Use the port in here. Go after Erimem. With a bit of luck they'll think we’ve both ported out of here and I can double back to the others.
But I
Just do it!
Okay.
Erimem?
Vidler? What are you doing here?
Looking for you. This is amazing. This must be the control room up on Medusa. I never imagined in
my wildest dreams
You can gawk later. I need your help.
With what? The reptile things?
You’ve seen them?
Just one. It didn’t seem very friendly.

They’re not, and there’s lots of them, I’m afraid. They’ve been living on this space station, breeding. The engine room is full of their eggs. But that means we have a chance. Eggs are vulnerable. If we act now we can destroy them before they hatch.
Destroy them? How are we going to do that?
I don’t know, but if you’ve got any ideas I'd love to hear them.
Ideas? Me? I don’t know. I’ve never had to destroy a horde of alien eggs before. I don’t know where to begin.
We begin by seeing what we’re dealing with. Every successful battle depends on good intelligence.
I can’t help thinking the intelligent thing to do would be to run away.
Stop twittering! You’re no better than Laroq.
Ah.
Now come on.
You have to believe me.
Oh, I do, Doctor. Butler, get back here now.
BUTLER [OC]: But Bellip...
I need you here now, Butler. That’s an order.

I think the Khellians have been coming here for some time, intercepting the candidates you’ve been trying to return home and taking them for their own needs. They must have stumbled on the space station and made a home on it.
You required me urgently, ma’am?
Yes, I do. Secure the Doctor.
What?
I am sorry, sir, but I need you to place your hands behind your back.
Auntie, this is madness. What do you think you’re doing? You have to listen to me. The lives of all your colonists depend on it.
Do you think I don’t know that?
I’m your only chance of survival.
Survival? Don’t lecture me on survival. I Know what the price of survival is, and believe me, I’ve been paying it.
You know.
Of course I know.
All of it? Do you know about the aliens and their visits and why they’re here?
Everything.
You’re a collaborator. You’ve sold out your own people to a race of aliens who want to feed on them.
That’s enough. Butler, if he says another word, kill him.
But
One word, Butler will do it. I mean, what’s one more death after so many?
Door opens and closes.
Laroq! Bellip!
Peri, what’s happening? Where’s Vidler?
On the space station.
Is he all right?
I hope so. What happened to the robot?
He ported out of here in a hurry.
Maybe there are more of these aliens about. We have to be careful.
Aliens? What are you talking about?
I just had a close encounter of the nearly fatal kind with a great big walking lizard.
But that’s not possible. Nobody ever comes here.
I’m here, aren’t I? Now come on.
Where are we going to go?
We need to find the Doctor.
There are hundreds of them.
And we have to destroy them all.
Smash them one by one? We’d be here forever.
I don’t know. There must be something we could use as a weapon. Let’s split up and look. Wait.
I thought we wanted to destroy them.
What was that sound?
It wasn’t me.
Vidler!
They’re hatching. They’re all beginning to hatch!

DOCTOR: Larder?
GENERAL: Larder, food store, pantry. I was hoping to get a bite to eat. Frozen would have been fine, but fresh meat is so much tastier.
ERIMEM: Fresh meat? Does this creature want to eat us?
GENERAL: Just one of you will suffice for now. No need to be greedy.
ERIMEM: No, no!
DOCTOR: Erimem...
DOCTOR: General! There was no need for violence.
GENERAL: You saw the girl run from me.
DOCTOR: She was trying to escape!
GENERAL: There is no escape from the Khellian Royal Guard.
PERI: That doesn’t get any better. The Doctor was lying. Bellip? Are you here?
BELLIP: Too big. I can’t deal with it.
PERI: Bellip, where are you? What is this place, some kind of lecture room?
BELLIP: I don’t know. It’s so large.
PERI: Oh, there you are. What are you doing under that desk?
BELLIP: I needed somewhere to hide.
PERI: From what?
BELLIP: I don’t know. After you left me, I was just filled with panic, so I dialled a random. I just wanted to get away, and I came here, and it’s so big!
PERI: It’s just a small hall.
BELLIP: It’s the biggest space I’ve ever been in. So big.
PERI: Bellip, don’t panic. Get a grip.
BELLIP: I can’t. It’s too much.
PERI: Bellip! Breathe like you did before. Slowly. Hold it in. That’s it. Then breathe out. That’s it. Just calm down. You're in control. You’re perfectly safe. You’re still inside. There’s a roof above you, and four walls around you.
BELLIP: (calmer) I’m sorry. You must think I’m an idiot.
PERI: It’s not your fault. It’s the way you’ve been brought up. You mustn’t feel bad.
BELLIP: Oh, but I do. You talked about the outside, about being in the open, but I can’t even enter a large room without having a panic attack. So how will I ever cope when I make the Return? Maybe that’s why I’ve never been chosen.
VIDLER: She should have been back by now.
LAROQ: How long has it been?
VIDLER: I don’t know. Five minutes? Ten? What's it matter? She was just going to port in and port back again to tell us where she went. Maybe she found something there she wasn’t expecting.
LAROQ: Like what?
VIDLER: I don’t know, do I?
LAROQ: Go after her, then.
VIDLER: What?
LAROQ: You want to do things, be proactive, don’t you? You’re always telling me that we’re too passive. So act. Do something. Follow Erimem. Find out what’s happened to her.
VIDLER: And leave you alone?
LAROQ: I'll cope. I might even prefer it.
VIDLER: I think we should wait a little longer.
LAROQ: Maybe she fainted in transit. Well, she’s not used to porting, is she?
VIDLER: In which case she’s probably in a heap on the port dais. I could use the recall.
LAROQ: Are you sure?
VIDLER: Okay, here goes.
LAROQ: Oh, nothing.
VIDLER: She must have stepped off the platform.
LAROQ: Or been taken off.
VIDLER: We can't stay here. If the Servitors catch us, we'll never get another chance like this to explore.
LAROQ: No. No, we should wait for Erimem.
VIDLER: You were just telling me to do something. We have to seize our chance. We might never get another opportunity like this. Make a mental note of the setting. We can always try and find her later.
LAROQ: You want to go back into the corridor?
VIDLER: I want to see where it goes. Are you coming?
LAROQ: I don’t know. No. Vid. Vidler! Wait, I’m coming! Don’t leave me.
DOCTOR: Erimem. She’s still breathing, thank goodness.
GENERAL: Step away from the female.
DOCTOR: What have you done to her? There was no call for that.
GENERAL: She was attempting to escape. Besides, it was a non-fatal charge. She will recover consciousness, eventually.
DOCTOR: You shot her in the back. What kind of soldier are you?
GENERAL: A hungry one. You’re not one of the colonists. Who are you?
DOCTOR: I’m the Doctor. I travel.
GENERAL: Really. How unfortunate for you.
DOCTOR: I’ve some things on my travels, some amazing sights, but I’ve rarely come across something as foul as I’ve discovered here.
GENERAL: And what is that, Doctor?
DOCTOR: You’ve turned this colony into some kind of farm, haven’t you?
GENERAL: Everyone has to eat.
DOCTOR: These colonists are sentient beings.
GENERAL: Meat is meat.
DOCTOR: No! How can any civilised creature eat something with which he’s just had a conversation?
GENERAL: As a rule, I don’t. I was always brought up not to play with my food.
DOCTOR: How long has this been going on?
GENERAL: That’s not your concern.
DOCTOR: I will not allow this to continue.
GENERAL: And who are you to stop a troop of trained warriors? Will you talk us into submission?
DOCTOR: I'll find a way.
GENERAL: I doubt that. You have no idea what you are dealing with, do you?
DOCTOR: Don’t I? The Khellian race. I’m sure I’ve heard of you. Let’s see. Brutal, militaristic, aggressive. Is that you?
GENERAL: How about respected, successful, all-conquering.
DOCTOR: It’s all a question of perspective.
GENERAL: The strong survive. The weak fall. It is the way of nature. We are all creatures on the food chain.

GENERAL: Khellians have developed survival suits for alien environments.

AUNTIE: Bellip? No.

PERI: How are you doing now?

DOCTOR: No, the General is from an alien reptilian race called the Khellians, and I doubt he‘s here alone.

DOCTOR: Khellian eggs, almost certainly. I’m trying to remember what I know about their life cycle. They have a Queen who produces thousands of eggs at a time, then dies. Until the eggs hatch, the Khellians are in a vulnerable state. The Queen’s Royal Guard must protect the brood at all costs.

DOCTOR: It’s simple. They've clearly been using the colony as some kind of farm. I fear it’s time for a harvest.

AUNTIE: That’s enough. Butler, if he says another word, kill him.
DOCTOR: But
AUNTIE: One word, Butler will do it. I mean, what’s one more death after so many?
PERI: Laroq! Bellip!
LAROQ: Peri, what’s happening? Where’s Vidler?
PERI: On the space station.
LAROQ: Is he all right?
PERI: I hope so. What happened to the robot?
LAROQ: He ported out of here in a hurry.
PERI: Maybe there are more of these aliens about. We have to be careful.
BELLIP: Aliens? What are you talking about?
PERI: I just had a close encounter of the nearly fatal kind with a great big walking lizard.
LAROQ: But that’s not possible. Nobody ever comes here.
PERI: I’m here, aren’t I? Now come on.
BELLIP: Where are we going to go?
PERI: We need to find the Doctor.
VIDLER: There are hundreds of them.
ERIMEM: And we have to destroy them all.
VIDLER: Smash them one by one? We’d be here forever.
ERIMEM: I don’t know. There must be something we could use as a weapon. Let’s split up and look. Wait.
VIDLER: I thought we wanted to destroy them.
ERIMEM: What was that sound?
VIDLER: It wasn’t me.
ERIMEM: Vidler!
VIDLER: They’re hatching. They’re all beginning to hatch!

elements.text: [Part Four]
Vidler, stay still.
What?
Look, they're moving past us, towards that corpse.
What are they doing to it?
I think they’re feeding on her.
Oh, that’s gross.
Mothers are always expected to provide for their offspring.
But not with their own flesh.
Come on. While they’re still weak and busy, let’s get out of here.
You just couldn’t keep your nose out, could you, Doctor?
Butler, listen to me. You're loyal to Auntie and to the colony. You’re not going to let her make a terrible mistake, are you?
You’re pushing your luck.
Perhaps we should listen to what the Doctor has to say.
I don’t want to hear anything he’s got to say.
Butler, tell me about the deal with the aliens. Is it to do with the other domes?
I gave you an order, Butler.
I cannot obey a flawed order. My ultimate duty is to the colony, not you.
The other domes are full of colonists in suspended animation, aren’t they? Colonists that were never defrosted at planettall.
Conditions were not right. We had to wait for the terraforming process to complete.
And it’s those sleeping colonists you’ve been sending up to the Khellians on Medusa, isn’t it? Food fresh from the freezer.
It was a logical solution to the problem of the Khellian presence on the space station.
Perhaps you could release my wrists now. I may not be as human as Auntie, but I do operate better with some blood reaching my hands.
Of course, Doctor.
I’m sorry, Auntie, but this has to stop right now.
What? What are you going to do now?
I’m going to beam back to the space station, whereupon I am going to do whatever it takes to stop the Khellians from harvesting any more colonists.
No! You'll just make things worse. I can’t let you. Stand away from that teleport pad. Butler, shoot the Doctor’s hand off if he so much as reaches for that control.
Auntie?
Butler, for the future of the colony.
Let me go and this colony may just have a future.
Teleport activates.
What? No!
It is too late. He’s gone. Someone must have recalled him from the station.
Well done, Erimem. I was beginning to worry that you weren’t paying attention.
We’ve only just got here.
We?
This is Vidler. Peri sent him here. Doctor, the eggs, they’re beginning to hatch.
Then we've got less time than I thought.
Doctor, won’t Auntie or Butler just follow you up here?
Not if I can throw a spanner in the works. There, that ought to do it.
What have you done?
He’s just used the override controls to shut down the transmat system’s buffers. Now the internal system cannot be accessed by anyone. The only way to move around is by foot.
But what about Peri?
Is she still on gamma deck?
She was when I left her, with Bellip and Laroq.

We should be able to see her from up here. A scan should do it. No, she’s not there. Let’s check the teleport activity. Ah, there she is. Location 458. Punch that code into this system here and we should be able to speak to her. Peri, can you hear me?
[OC]: Doctor? Where are you?
Never mind about that. You need to get out of there as quickly as possible.
[OC]: Easier said than done. There are some aliens down here who want to have us to dinner, and I don’t mean as guests.
I know. Listen to me. We can access schematics of the colony ship and guide you to an airlock.
[OC]: With these guys? Are you kidding? They’re freaked enough being out of their rooms.
You have to get off the ship, Peri.
[OC]: Okay. Game for a laugh. How do we keep in touch?
There are intercoms at every port terminal. Just note the access code 230.
[OC]: 230. Got it.
Right then. Erimem, Vidler, this is a schematic of the colony ship. Peri and her friends are here and they need to get to here, to the airlock. Can you talk her through it?
I think so, but wouldn’t you be better at this?

I’m going to try and reason with Auntie, but this time I'll take the Tardis. Keeping the teleport system offline is in all our interests. We can’t use it to move around on the surface but equally the General can’t use it to return up here. They’re trapped on the colony ship.
But what about the alien eggs?
Have you secured the doors to the engine room?
Yes, but they won’t hold against a sustained attack.
We have to deal with them while they’re still weak. What’s the power source on this station?
Nuclear fusion.
Can you find a way to remove the radiation shields from the generators?
I can try.
Will that stop them?
I’m afraid it will. I don’t see that we have any other choice.
[OC]: Okay, we’re ready to move out. Which way?
Good luck to both of you.
The Tardis dematerialises.
Hey, that’s neat. A personalised transmat.
It’s more than that. It’s home. And seeing it disappear like that, I realise one day I will watch it fade away and it will never come back.
Hey, don’t worry. The Doctor won't leave you.
Won't he?
[OC]: Hey guys, I could use some directions down here.
Sorry, Peri. Let me see where you need to go.
There’s nothing I can do. The system is locked and the override is controlled from the space station.
And without the teleport, we can’t get there. We’re trapped.
The Tardis materialises.
What in the name of goodness is that?
I believe it is the Doctor’s vehicle.
Tardis door opens.
Don’t shoot. We need to talk.
Tardis door closes.
Doctor, you have to unlock the transmat override.
I don’t think that’s a very good idea.
I’m the leader of this colony. I know what’s best for my people.
Do you really? And in what way is feeding them wholesale to a bunch of starving reptiles best for them?
I had no choice.
We always have choices, Auntie.
All right, maybe I did. That’s what leadership is about, isn’t it? Making the hard choices. But I was being pragmatic.
Pragmatic?

You have to understand. We had nowhere to go. The transmat relays back to the Federation had broken down. We were forgotten, cut off, withering on the vine. Sunspot activity had set the terraforming process back by decades. And then the Khellians found us.
And they couldn’t believe their luck. A nice space station to inhabit, a supply of food, a perfect set-
up in which to produce a new brood.

They offered me a deal, a chance for my family to survive. One by one the Khellians have taken the members of my family to the space station, and sent them by hyperspace transmat link to another Federation colony.
And you believe that?
We had a deal, and I believe the Khellians are honourable.
I don’t. No one has escaped.
Of course they have.

Auntie, I’ve been on the space station. Check the records. There have been no deep space transits. Your family have been farmed alongside the other colonists you’ve sent to their deaths. The Khellians like fresh meat as well as frozen.
No! No! I just had to buy some time, time to get the planet ready to sustain us. Then I was planning to revive the survivors in the other domes. We would have had the numbers then to fight back.
You can still do that.
No, I, I need you to do something else for me. There is still one member of my family in the colony. Bellip, my granddaughter.
I see.
My daughter’s only daughter. Perhaps part of me always knew. I kept her back where I could see her. Please, make sure she survives.
I'll do what I can.
How are you holding up, Bellip?
I don’t feel very well. I’m not sure I can do this.
Of course you can. Lean on Larogq.
It’s okay, Bellip. We’re nearly there.
Let me check in with Erimem. Erimem? We’re at teleport terminal on D deck. Now where?
Be patient, Peri, please. Right. Turn right, and go until the 8", no, 9" door. It’s in there.
Okay. I'll call when we get there. Let’s move it then.
Are they oxygen breathers?
I think so.
You realise this is the original colony ship?
It’s not hard to see when you look.
The engines are useless, but most internal systems are still functioning, including the life support systems. It can be sealed and drained of oxygen.
I don't like to kill.
It’s kill or be killed, Doctor. Those creatures will eat you and your companions as quickly as they will eat us.
I fear you’re right.
But we need a distraction. If the aliens notice the change in the atmosphere too soon, they'll have time to try and escape.
Well, the General already wants my blood, which makes me the obvious candidate to be bait.
Let Butler be your guide. He knows the ship even better than its designers.
I'll take your word for that. Now, there are only a handful of adult Khellians, and there are none on the space station right now. Can you operate the life support from here?
I can do it all from here.
Come on then, let’s go and find out what hunting feels like from the sharp end.
Step inside the airlock, then.
It’s just a small room. There’s nothing in here.
Except another set of doors.
Let’s just close these behind us.
I like this. I feel safe here.
It might be a good idea for you to close your eyes for the next bit.
Computer, access internal climate control.
System activated.
Initiate total atmosphere drain from all parts of the ship.
Venting atmosphere will create conditions that are hostile to life.
I’m aware of that. How long?
Please restate the question.
How long before oxygen levels are low enough for anyone out there to notice?
Air breathing lifeforms will begin to suffer symptoms of oxygen deprivation in approximately
thirteen minutes. Total vacuum will be achieved in sixteen minutes.
Too long. Too long.
(distant) They must be somewhere. Find me the Doctor. I should like to taste his flesh myself.
That sounds like our man.
Wait here, Doctor. Let me prime the hunt.
Who goes there? Ah, the android. Come here.
General Makra’Thon, how may I be of service?
Where is the creature who calls himself the Doctor?
He is not a colonist. I have no information.
Access your system computer. I have to know where he is.
The latest information I have is that he is at large somewhere in this colony ship. The teleport system is currently non-functioning, so the Doctor must be travelling by foot.
Then I shall hunt him down. Assign Servitors to assist me.
I am very sorry, General. All Servitors are required to repair the transmat system.
In that case, we will do it ourselves.
Sound of wind. Bellip whimpering.
What, what is it?
That is the surface of your planet. It’s your home.
But, but where is the ceiling?
Well, there isn’t one. Just go straight up and you'll hit that space station of yours
I feel sick.
We can’t stop now, we’ve come so far. You see that dome? That’s where we have to go.
Across the open space?
It’s only about a hundred yards.
It might as well be a hundred miles. I can’t go out there.
You have to!
I think I might manage it, but not without help.
Okay then, we'll do this in relays. Bellip, wait here. Do the breathing exercise I taught you.
Okay.
And try not to panic. Laroq? Let’s go.
Walking.
Vidler always said it was our destiny to feel the sun on our backs.
Maybe he was right. Just concentrate on putting one foot after the other. And don’t look up.
Weapons fire obscuring some dialogue.
You know, this might not have been such a good idea.
You can run, Doctor, but not forever.
I only need just long enough.
My men are [unintelligible]. You’re only putting off the inevitable. I look forward to tasting your flesh.
This way, Doctor.
What? Where are you?
In here, quick. There are more Khellians.
Door closes.

Now what, Butler? Out in the corridor there are Khellians in each direction, and now we’re trapped ina small room with a defunct teleport terminal and not a lot of options. This is not going to plan at all.
Oxygen levels at 96% optimum and falling.
This is taking too long.
The ship is a large repository of atmosphere.
There must be another way. Of course. Computer. Arm self-destruct.
Executive authority is required.
On my authority as leader.
Confirm identity. Retinal scan required.
Here, read my eye. Satisfied?
Commander identity confirmed. Self-destruct armed. System parameters ready.
Initiate total self-destruct on the ship on a ten minute countdown. On my mark. Mark!
Countdown has begun.
And computer, I need access to the munitions store. Belt and braces, as my father used to say. Belt and braces.
Ah, it’s no good. I just can’t do it from here. The system isn’t designed to give access to the generators from this control centre.
There must be something we can do.
I need to go back into the engine room. I'll have to do it the old-fashioned way. I can release the radiation shields by hand.
Wouldn't that be dangerous?
Not if I beam out as soon as I’ve done it.
But the Doctor disabled your transmats.
I can show you how to reverse that. Give me five minutes, then initiate this programme.
What will that do?
That will open up the buffers for one minute. Long enough for me to port out.
Are you sure about this?

If the little aliens start nipping at my legs, the radiation suit should protect me for long enough to do what I have to do. Don’t worry, Erimem. Laroq is always telling me I’m all talk and no action. Perhaps I can prove him wrong.
Alarm.
What’s that?
Some kind of alarm, from the colony ship. Oh no. You need to get hold of Peri. Fast.
There, you made it. Rest now.
Oh, thank you, Peri. I couldn’t have done it without you.
I'd better get back to Bellip.
[OC]: Peri? Peri, are you there yet?
Erimem? We just got here. What’s up?
[OC]: Something’s happened. You’ve got less time than we thought.
What is it?
[OC]: According to the computer systems on the space station, the colony ship has been set to self- destruct.
What? But the Doctor...
[OC]: We don’t understand it either, but you’ve got three minutes to get clear. Hurry.
Larog, stay here, and be ready to close these doors the second Bellip and I get here.
There is another way out of here.
Let me guess. A ventilation shaft.
A service tunnel, designed to allow Servitors to move about without disturbing the crew.
I'm a little larger than most of your Servitors.
I think you will manage. Quickly. I will replace the cover when you have entered.
I think I might need to go on a diet.
[OC]: Get this door open.
If I’m not to be part of someone else’s diet, I think I’d better get going.
Cover replaced, door opens.
Servitor, I thought you were meant to be aiding us.
How may I be of service?
The Doctor, are you hiding him? Step away from that wall.
I’m sorry, I cannot do that.
Move or I'll fire.
If you must.
Weapons fire.
You have damaged this unit.
Damaged? Damn. I was hoping for total destruction.
Weapons fire, kaBoom.
(sotto) Erimem, can you hear me?
[OC]: Vidler, where are you now?
(sotto) Inside the engine room. The rad suit has a communications channel.
[OC]: What are the aliens doing?
(sotto) Most of them are still eating. They don’t seem to have noticed me yet.
[OC]: Can you remove the shields?
(sotto) I’m just trying to bypass the safety protocols now. That’s done it. Right, here goes. You’d better stand by to get the teleports back online.
Crash.
Who's there?
It’s just me. Now I remember why I usually get my companions to do the crawling around in small spaces. How are we doing?
A dozen Khellians have joined the General.
That’s probably the entire Guard. What about the atmospheric drain? The air felt a bit thin in the service corridor, but it was a bit cramped in there.
It’s taking some time, so I have made other arrangements.
Other arrangements?
One minute to ship self-destruct.
What have you done?
I wanted to be certain that they would die.
On your feet, Bellip. We’re going for a little run.
I’m not ready.
You have to be. Come on.
It’s so big. So much space.
Just take it one step at a time. Come on, you can do it.
It’s hard, so hard.
Just one step and then another. Close your eyes. Hold onto me and walk. Imagine you’re in your room walking on your exerciser.
I like walking on my exerciser.
It’s just like that, but we need to pick up the pace a little. Give yourself a proper workout.
What’s that moving?
What? Oh, it’s the wind. Just the wind.
It pushed me.
It’s just air. Moving air. Don’t panic.
Transmat.
Vidler, are you okay?
I think so. Help me off with this rad suit, will you?
Transmat.
Oh no.
Self-destruct has been activated. Evacuate the ship. This is not a drill. Repeat, this is not a drill.
We have to go.
Has your friend got clear?
I hope so.
And Bellip?
I don’t know, but if we don’t get out of here we’ll never know. Come on.
Tardis door opens.
Fifteen.
Tardis door closes, Tardis dematerialises.
Fourteen, thirteen, twelve, eleven, ten, nine, eight, seven
Come on! We have to get to cover!
There’s danger? I knew the outside was dangerous.
There’s nothing out here to be scared of. It’s the ship we just left that might kill us.
I don’t understand.
If we don’t get inside that dome, we'll go with it. Larog, be ready with that door! Now!
KaBoom, clang.
What happened?
That explosion was your colony ship.
Our habitat cells.
Your prison cells, you mean. You don’t need them any more. You’re free now.
Free? Free for what?
Free to live your lives.
We don’t know what that means.
I guess you’ll just have to figure it out, then.
KaBoom then a series of smaller explosions. Scanner off.
It’s done.
Perhaps. Let’s hop back to the space station, collect Erimem, and survey the damage.
At least I can have the satisfaction of knowing that Makra’Thon is dead.
I hope that knowledge helps you sleep at night.
Tardis materialises, Tardis door opens.
I’ve not been up here for years.
Tardis door closes.
Welcome back. Erimem!
Doctor, I
I think we might have written off the General too soon.
Doctor, I told you that the end of the hunt was inevitable.
Let Erimem and the boy go. Your quarrel is with me, not them.
My quarrel is with all of you. My crew has been wiped out by the savagery of you animals.
You ate my colonists, and you call us animals?

You don’t understand. That is not all we are. We have culture, art, civilisation. We build things, not just destroy them. We keep ourselves to ourselves, unlike you humans. Even in our isolated part of the galaxy we have heard of you and of your hypocrisy.
What are you talking about?

You humans, you spread through the universe, bringing your narrow-minded ideas of right and wrong, and claim moral high ground, and yet all the time you are no better than we Khellians. How many times in your history have you been responsible for death and destruction on a massive scale?
You’re right. Humans have done some questionable things. But that’s no excuse to treat them like cattle.
I don’t wish to argue. Destroying you is what I must do to protect the eggs.
Ah. You may be a little late for that.
The brood? What of them?
Oh, nothing much. Just that they’re all dying from radiation poisoning.
No! You have guaranteed yourselves a terrible death.
Are you all right, General? You seem a little wobbly on your feet. Still recovering from the thin air of the colony ship, are you?
Get back.
You can’t shoot all of us.
Can't I? Don’t wriggle, girl.
I’m not wriggling, I’m bracing to kick!
Down, Erimem!
Out of the way. Let me at him.
Erimem, over here.
Get off me, fool,
No way. I owe this to the rest of my family, who you butchered!
Auntie, no!
Get back!
Bang! Sloshing liquid.
What happened?
Auntie must have been carrying a bomb of some sort.
A low level detonator, actually. Useful for terraformers facing the task of excavating hard ground or vile alien stomachs.
Auntie, are you...
Fine, but it would be nice if someone could help me get this disgusting creature’s corpse off me.
Of course.
Doctor, where’s Peri?
Down below, safe and well, I hope.
As our survivors in the other domes. Perhaps now we should wake them.
To go home?
Maybe. Maybe not. You claim to be a scientist.
I have some ability in that field, yes.
Then perhaps you could help me use the Medusa’s scanners to evaluate the terraforming project.
Yes, I’d be happy to.
The Tardis materialises.
Oh, at last. I was beginning to worry.
Tardis door opens.
Peri! Ah, there you are. You made it then.
Just about. Whose bright idea was it to blow the ship up?
That was me, I’m afraid.
Thanks very much. You nearly took us with it.
Well, I’m glad to see she didn't.
Erimem! Good to see you.
It is good to see you too, Peri.
What happens now?
Well, generally we like to make a quiet getaway and let people get on with it.
Get on with what? Everything we’ve ever known has gone.
Not quite everything.
Vidler!
Steady in there. Personal space and all that.
We have to get past all that.
It’s a new beginning.
With just the four of us?
Just four? I don’t think so. Do you, Auntie?
No, I don’t. There are a dozen domes like this one, and plenty of colonists still in suspended animation. We’ll revive them, and start working at making this colony work.
But the soil, the atmosphere. I thought this planet couldn’t sustain life.

It couldn’t when we arrived, but a long-term terraforming project began the moment we landed. The soil has been enriched with nitrates, an ozone layer has been created, water levels have been improved.

According to the monitors on Medusa, the terraforming changes have almost reached a certain critical mass. A corner has very nearly been turned. It won't be easy, but it will get easier from this point on. I think this colony does have a future.
But the Khellians?
I’m afraid that I don’t think that they do.
Are you sure you will not stay? The three of you, you can help us rebuild normal lives.
I'm flattered, but I’m not really the organiser sort. I like a certain amount of disorder, to be totally honest. Anyway, you have Auntie to lead you.
I don’t think so. I’ve done enough of that, and made too many mistakes. It’s time for someone new, someone younger. Some fresh blood.
But where will we find someone suitable?
Well, I do know someone who has some experience of leadership. You might even say she was born to it.
Me?
Might you be up to the challenge?
I’m sure I could, but I would rather carry on travelling with you.
You would?
Oh yes. There’s still so much I want to see and learn.
Splendid. I’m sorry, Auntie. You and your colonists are going to have to work this out yourselves. Perhaps together, between you.
Share the burden, you mean.
Worth a go, isn’t it?
I’m glad you’re staying.
I had to. You promised to show me a roller-coaster.
Goodbye, then. And good luck.
Tardis door closes, Tardis dematerialises.
Right then, where’s next?
Earth!
But first, Peri owes me a pedicure.
Yes, your Majesty.
I’ll be in my room.
I think she’s back to her old self, don’t you?
Well on the road to recovery. And what about you? Any regrets?
Too few to mention.
So, you’re absolutely sure that you do want both of us around?
Of course I do. You know, two’s company, but three... Three’s a crew.

VIDLER: What?
ERIMEM: Look, they're moving past us, towards that corpse.
VIDLER: What are they doing to it?
ERIMEM: I think they’re feeding on her.
VIDLER: Oh, that’s gross.
ERIMEM: Mothers are always expected to provide for their offspring.
VIDLER: But not with their own flesh.
ERIMEM: Come on. While they’re still weak and busy, let’s get out of here.
AUNTIE: You just couldn’t keep your nose out, could you, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Butler, listen to me. You're loyal to Auntie and to the colony. You’re not going to let her make a terrible mistake, are you?
AUNTIE: You’re pushing your luck.
BUTLER: Perhaps we should listen to what the Doctor has to say.

DOCTOR: Perhaps you could release my wrists now. I may not be as human as Auntie, but I do operate better with some blood reaching my hands.
BUTLER: Of course, Doctor.
DOCTOR: I’m sorry, Auntie, but this has to stop right now.
AUNTIE: What? What are you going to do now?
DOCTOR: I’m going to beam back to the space station, whereupon I am going to do whatever it takes to stop the Khellians from harvesting any more colonists.
AUNTIE: No! You'll just make things worse. I can’t let you. Stand away from that teleport pad. Butler, shoot the Doctor’s hand off if he so much as reaches for that control.
BUTLER: Auntie?
AUNTIE: Butler, for the future of the colony.
DOCTOR: Let me go and this colony may just have a future.
AUNTIE: What? No!
BUTLER: It is too late. He’s gone. Someone must have recalled him from the station.
DOCTOR: Well done, Erimem. I was beginning to worry that you weren’t paying attention.
ERIMEM: We’ve only just got here.
DOCTOR: We?
ERIMEM: This is Vidler. Peri sent him here. Doctor, the eggs, they’re beginning to hatch.
DOCTOR: Then we've got less time than I thought.
ERIMEM: Doctor, won’t Auntie or Butler just follow you up here?
DOCTOR: Not if I can throw a spanner in the works. There, that ought to do it.
ERIMEM: What have you done?
VIDLER: He’s just used the override controls to shut down the transmat system’s buffers. Now the internal system cannot be accessed by anyone. The only way to move around is by foot.
ERIMEM: But what about Peri?
DOCTOR: Is she still on gamma deck?
VIDLER: She was when I left her, with Bellip and Laroq.
DOCTOR: We should be able to see her from up here. A scan should do it. No, she’s not there. Let’s check the teleport activity. Ah, there she is. Location 458. Punch that code into this system here and we should be able to speak to her. Peri, can you hear me?
PERI: [OC]: Doctor? Where are you?
DOCTOR: Never mind about that. You need to get out of there as quickly as possible.
